title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs a very enthusiastic, though amateur, photographer, I had treated myself to a new and rather expensive camera lens.Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this – why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: letters week 12
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,This is a short note of thanks to all who made my th birthday party at Chalmers Court such a success.I did not help a great deal by having a bad fall near the bus stop on my way for the morning papers and am lucky not to have broken bones. A bruised and battered face caused alarm on first viewing which gave way to quite a lot of laughter and bold comment.But what a delightful party, laid on by our warden Sheena Stewart and ladies and saw we all had tea, coffee, and home baking, including shortbread and sconesand presents of wine and malt whiskey. What a lovely morning.To all who sent cards for my th, including the community council, the Wednesday Club, the Inveraray Highland Games , my warmest thanks. And many thanks to those who helped me up after my fall and in particular Stuart Campbell of Brambles who took me to the surgery, whose very kind people cleaned me up and sent me on my way to my party half an hour later.And a mention to Take the Floor too on Radio Scotland on Saturday night. Thank you Inveraray and District Accordion and Fiddle Club and Margaret Mather our secretary for this request.So I won#t forget my th in a hurry, but such kindness and friendliness cannot be forgotten ever.My thanks to you all,Niall Iain MacLean, InveraraySir,I read with great interest the letter in the March  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser from C Rees, Lochgilphead.In addition to all that was mentioned I wonderyour readers are acquainted with the McCrone Report which was written in the s As I’m sure your readers are aware this was when oil had just started flowing from the North Sea. Mr Gavin McCrone was, at that time, a civil servant instructed to write a report on the possible effects of North Sea Oil on the argument for Scotland’s devolution.This quote comes from a letter written, by Mr McCrone, in April : #The Paper was written over a year ago in the weeks immediately before the February  election. This will be particularly apparent on page  where, of course, the ministerial pronouncements referred to relate to the Conservative Government.#So he was instructed to write this report by a Conservative Government but was reporting to a Labour Government.This quote comes from the end of the letter: #When my paper was written it was classied “secret” and given only a most restricted circulation in the Scottish Office because of the extreme sensitivity of the subject.#The report discussed the possibility of Scottish Independence and came to the conclusion: #What is quite clear is that the balance of payments gain from North Sea oil would easily swamp the existing deficit whatever its size and transform Scotland into a country with a substantial and chronic surplus.#Now, this is a very tiny segment from a document that could have changed our history but that’s in the past and we must now look to the future.What is upsetting is thatthis wealth had been invested in an oil fund or more fairly distributed by the  British Government # either Conservative or Labour # there might not, now, be an upsurge in support for separation from Westminster.Wilma Watts, TarbertSir,With Theresa May’s Brexit deal yet again failing to get through the House of Commons and a delay to the date the UK is due to leave the EU, it is clear that we are simply lurching from crisis to crisis.One wonders what good an extension will actually do given the negotiating position of both the EU and the UK. The UK is deadlocked, in terms of its people, Parliament and Cabinet and the likelihood of any semblance of a deal that command the majority of the House of Commons is unlikely. This is especially true given the deep isions within the Tories, both Remainers and Leavers, as well as opposition from the DUP.Given this situation those like myself have long argued that a UK-wide referendum on the deal, a so-called ‘People’s Vote’, with the option to remain in the EU, is the only credible way to break this deadlock. For those who argue that this would damage our democratic process, I am not sure we can slump any lower than the situation we are currently in.As David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary and an ardent Leaver, pointed out before the EU referendum: #If a democracy cannot change its mind, it ceases to be a democracy.#There are few I know who voted for Brexit in the belief it would make them poorer, and it is up to the public to give its view on whether the deal, and more importantly its implications, are what it wants.For once I agree with Jacob Rees-Mogg who previously supported a vote on the renegotiated settlement. A statement he now curiously seems to have forgotten.The Scottish Parliament has led the way in backing a People’s Vote and now that we know the precise nature of the deal, it is up to the public to have its say.Alex Orr, Edinburgh

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a £, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: bob shields public need say
story: NewsBob Shields: Public need say on Prime Ministers Brexit dealReal democracy is having a second voteShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsBlundering Theresa May heads the most incompetent Government weve had in living memory "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHow many Members of Parliament does it take to change a light bulb  The answer – of course - is just one. But it takes the other  of them over two and a half years to decide exactly what kind of light bulb they want in its place! In last week’s episode of Commons Comedy Capers, we had the Brexit secretary proposing the Government’s motion . . . then voting against it. Similarly, we had the Chief Whip – whose job is make sure MPs toe the party line – voting against his party line! Last Tuesday MPs rejected Theresa May’s deal, on Wednesday the rejected ‘No Deal’ and on Thursday they rejected sticking to the March  deadline. I watched the creaking, croaking Theresa at Prime Minister’s Questions and it looked like the only thing you could guarantee to be behind May . . . was June! When it comes to Brexit, the House of Commons has now had more votes than most Eurovision Song Contests. And as I write this on a dreary Monday afternoon – it seems certain that another vote is on the way. Theresa May is going to put her ‘deal’ to the Commons for a THIRD time . . . but onlyshe’s confident that she’ll win it! Yes folks – a vote ONLYshe knows she’ll win in advance. How’s that for democracy at work  So - we have a vote . . . another vote . . . and then another vote  Mmm – now where have I heard that before  Ah yes – now I remember - it’s been the Conservative party’s official ‘put down’ of every single request for a second “people’s referendum” on Brexit. It’s a line you can even trace it back to the lips of our very own Member of Parliament, Mr Bill Grant. “We have already had a ‘people’s vote”, he said. “Another vote, assuming it indicated a dferent outcome, would be presumably followed by another vote and another vote, and so on”. What Bill, and the Conservatives, have been telling us for months is that you can’t keep on having a vote until you get the result you want. But meanwhile, the leader of the Conservative party is doing exactly that! And it’s not asthe Prime Minister needs a five per cent swing – the dference in the Euro referendum – to get her own way. It beggars belief that she can take the biggest parliamentary hiding in history . . .and go back for a second and even a third bite at the cherry! It begs the obvious question –our MPs can get three chances to vote on the biggest political issue of our generation – why can’t the ‘people’ get at least a second vote  I’m also getting fed up with Brexiteers telling us “the public just want this pushed over theline so they can move on”.Er . . . no. The public I speak to want the right deal to leave Europe. Andit’s not on the table, theywant the right to reject it and stay in Europe. Is it too late to ask Bill Grant to stop puckering in the direction of Theresa May and start pointing his ears in the direction of his constituency, which not only voted to “remain” but voted him to Parliament to represent them  I hope not. Bill’s qualities might include loyalty . . . but he’s always open minded. My solution  Well, it might be a bit simplistic – but then most solutions are.  Parliament instructs the PM to ask to delay Article  for one year.  Parliament instructs the PM to form a cross-party Brexit Committee to begin new talks – and come back with the best deal that the combined parties have negotiated and will have support in Parliament.  Give the public an unbiased and detailed explanation of what the deal means. Put it to a referendum – accept the deal and leave – or reject the deal and remain. This way, the people of Britain - and Europe - will know exactly where they stand.By March   – we’re in or we’re out. And everyone, on every side, will have had their say. Bill, that’s real democracy at work.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnConservative PartyAyrBrexit

story: Picture by contracted freelance Steve McKendrick"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA gran who hurled bleach over a child has been granted a personal licence to sell alcohol by East Ayrshire council. Mary McLelland was convicted of throwing the cleaning agent over a -year-old boy’s head and body in Auchinleck. Police objected to McLelland getting a personal licence at the council’s licensing board meeting heard last week, McLelland, , of Main Street, Auchinleck carried out the crime in November . Police Sergeant David Dougan told councillors McLelland was sentenced to a community payback order at Ayr Sherf Court last year as punishment. But McLelland said she was plagued by anti-social behaviour outside at her home in Main Street. She told the board: “I love kids. I regret it.” She claims she has had problems with people “chapping her door” and urinating in her garden. She rushed out to the nearby bus shelter during one incident, she told the meeting.. McLelland said: “I went out. It wasn’t even raw bleach. It is not an excuse. I shouldn’t have done it.” She claimed the bottle was kicked out of her hand and spilled over the victim. But the meeting heard McLelland pled guilty in court. The shop worker said: “I am not in the habit of going out and fighting with kids. “I am a -year-old woman.” She added: “Everybody in this le makes mistakes. Nobody in this world is perfect.” She told the meeting she had phoned the police numerous times to report anti-social behaviour at her property. Councillors adjourned the meeting to discuss whether she should be handed a licence. Ontheir opinion was split with three councillors voting to grant her application and the same number against. Board Chair Councillor Tom Cook had the ruling say and decided to grant McLelland’s licence. He said giving her the licence would not increase her chances of committing a similar offence in the future. Councillors George Mair, John Campbell and Fiona Campbell voted to refuse the licence. Councilors Drew Filson, Lillian Jones supported Councillor Cook’s view to grant it. Councillor Cook said he would grant the licence “albeit with reservations.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnEast Ayrshire CouncilCourtsJusticeAyr

title: people say future high rise
story: NewsPeople to have their say on the future of high-rise flats in AyrTenants asked for their preferred optionShareByGary Fanning:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTenants in the Riverside Place multi-storey flats in Ayr are getting the chance to have their say on the future of the high-rise properties as South Ayrshire Council’s consultation on ‘Your place, your future’ gets underway. The consultation and engagement exercise – approved by Councillors last year – gives tenants the chance to choose their preferred option for the long-term future of the flats: Refurbish  – this means the Council would keep the flats, decant tenants, carry out identied refurbishment works, and thentenants to their refurbished flats. Rehouse  – this means tenants would be rehoused permanently in suitable alternative accommodation and the flats would be demolished. Rebuild  – this means tenants would be decanted to temporary accommodation and the flats would be demolished before some tenantsto a new-build housing development on the Riverside Place site. The detailed consultation, which is based around inidual one-to-one meetings with more than  tenants, has been planned in conjunction with the River Ayr Tenants Association, which represents tenants in the three blocks. The Council has communicated regularly with tenants in the lead-up to the consultation to ensure they have all the information they need to take part. A further letter has now been distributed to homes in Riverside Place following queries and concerns raised by tenants regarding a letter sent to them by Fort, Seafield  Wallacetown Community Council. The community council’s letter appears to query the three consultation options being discussed with tenants and questions South Ayrshire Council’s interpretation of the expert report approved last year regarding the “essential and advisable” works required to the flats. Councillor Philip Saxton, South Ayrshire Council’s Portfolio Holder for Housing and Community Wellbeing, said: “We are committed to ensuring that our tenants are fully involved in the discussions about the future of their flats, which is why we’re taking such a detailed approach to this consultation. “It’s vital that tenants understand all the facts so they can form their own views about the option that is best for them. That is why we have gone back out to them to respond to the queries and confusion that have been generated by the community council’s letter. “We fully appreciate that the community council may have a view on the consultation, which is why colleagues are meeting with them next week and we’re happy to keep them informed about the consultation and engagement process. “However, our focus – which was clearly expressed by tenants at the recent River Ayr Tenants Association meeting – has to be on hearing the views of those who will be directly affected by Councillors’ decisions later this year: the tenants of Riverside Place. “We thank them for their participation in the consultation and I can reassure them that their views will be taken into account before any decisions are taken about the future of Riverside Place.” Joe Lafferty, Chair of the River Ayr Tenants Association, said: “We have worked closely with the Council over the last couple of years as discussions around the future of the flats have moved forward – and we very much appreciate the approach the Council has taken. “It is for every tenant to consider what is the best option for them and to ensure their voice is heard by those who will be making the decisions about what happens next. Clear facts, easy to understand information and answers to the questions tenants have is what’s needed and that’s exactly what we have got from the Council.”   Feedback from the consultation will be considered by Councillors in June this year.Full details of the Riverside Place consultation are available at  www.south-ayrshire.gov.uk riverside-place . title: plans luxury flats prestwicks malcolm
story: NewsPlans for luxury flats at Prestwicks Malcolm Sargent House are scrappedDevelopers have dropped their proposal to build on the famous site at the seafront.ShareByPaul Behan:,  MAR NewsArchitects plans for the retirement flats "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPlans to build luxury flats at the former Malcolm Sargent holiday retreat for sick kids in Prestwick have been binned. The Post can exclusively reveal that the developers McCarthy  Stone have thrown in the towel and withdrawn their multi-million pound proposals. Major question marks hang over the building’s future following the bombshell announcement. The news prompted an angry backlash from Derek Hart, chair of Prestwick North Community Council. In an extraordinary outburst he claimed the building has been “plundered and left to rot.” The building provided a retreat for children battling cancer for more than  years. It was opened by Princess Diana in . In  it was sold by owners Clic Sargent after claims of a “challenging fundraising environment”. They sold it to McCarthy  Stone and trousered £.m from the deal. However, since McCarthy  Stone took ownership and unveiled their luxury flat plans they have been embroiled in a bitter fight with neighbours Prestwick Golf Club. The club was opposed to the development on the basis of its scale and design. Other objections included the potential impact it would have had on their historic course and the surrounding conservation area. In addition, there were fears that errant balls could smash into residents’ properties. Plans involved building  flats for people aged over , spread out in a T-shape over four floors. Many would have had sea views and balconies. The proposals were approved by South Ayrshire Council but last year Prestwick Golf Club successfully petitioned for a judicial review, meaning demolition work on the former retreat had to stop. It was estimated that  jobs would be created between the construction phase and posts at the new development. Despite a PR charm offensive from McCarthy  Stone throughout the process and a public exhibition of plans at the  Club in Prestwick’s Main Street, the developers pulled the plug on the project. A spokesperson said: “Following a strategic review last year we are no longer pursuing any new developments within Scotland and have withdrawn our plans for Prestwick.” Derek Hart reckons the decision is a kick in the teeth for all the campaigners who fought to retain the presence of a sick children’s home in Prestwick. He told the Post: “I find this action taken by McCarthy  Stone not only deplorable but a slap in the face to the Save Malcolm Sargent House team who fought bravely to try to purchase it. “Is it not time for South Ayrshire Council to stop and listen to the community  “The community stated that the development would only feather the nests of McCarthy  Stone – and perhaps chemists –as the age group targeted by them were over  years. “There’s been very little input to Prestwick and we are now left with a building that has been plundered and left to rot. “Will we find the same response to the other end of the beach, at the old Gym, I wonder ”He added: “Time after time SAC have allowed developers to build as they wish with barely a challenge to the character ofthe town and how it should look.”The news will be viewed as a major victory for Prestwick Golf Club, who fought long and hard against the development. A statement by the club said: “While we welcome this news we hope that, should a new development proposal for the site be put forward in the future, the design and scale will be more sympathetic to the surrounding area.” The statement said the club was not against the principle of redeveloping the site but was “disappointed” at the scale and design of the proposed development. It added: “We believed that McCarthy  Stone hadn’t listened to the concerns raised by the club.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnPrincess DianaSouth Ayrshire CouncilRoyal FamilyPrestwickAyr NewsAyr

title: sisters act sibling fiona stricken
story: NewsSisters Act for sibling Fiona, stricken by strokesThousands of pounds raised for Stroke Association by Prestwick pairShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR NewsAfter the race - Gaenor, Gillian and young Graham "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe strokes struck without warning to a lady in her prime. Super-fit Fiona McBlane was , practised yoga and cycled and was in London lapping up a glamorous working le in the music industry for companies such as EMI and Smash Hits. But during a Christmas visit home to Ayrshire she fell unwell with leg, arm and head pain. Such was her distress she admitted herself to hospital. First the minor stroke hit - on January ,  - and then the searing biggie nine days later. It left her semi-paralysed in hospital for  months, unable to speak, hardly walking and retaining very limited brain capacity. That was when Clan McBlane rallied round to give her the best future they could. They had been advised the best place for her was an old folks home but they stood firm. Once Fiona was fit enough to leave hospital she was brought into the bosom of the family in Prestwick. Twelve years on at the age of , Fiona is battling away and has got to the stage where she has joined the gym at Prestwick Tennis Club. Her loving older sisters Gillian McBlane, , and -year-old Gaenor Hardy have just pounded round the Stroke Association’s Resolution Run with Gillian’s -year-old son Graham to continue raising money for the charity. That added £ to a total now of about £. Gillian, a top civil lawyer in Ayr, and Gaenor, headmistress at Heathfield Primary, assist their parents Jean and Ian who are Fiona’s full-time carers. And Gillian is helped by the other legal eagle in the family, Ayr criminal defence agent Steven Maxwell. Gillian said: “She loved her work and was a real high flier. “People were drawn to Fiona’s fun-loving nature and her great big heart. “Never for a minute did we think she would have a stroke. “At  years old she had lost everything she loved.” Fiona is prone to falling and choking, often passing out. Sometimes the enormity of what has happened becomes too much for her and she struggles emotionally. But Gillian said: “Our parents taught us to look for the positive things in le and not to feel sorry for ourselves. We spend time together and Fiona enjoys the company. “Despite the extent of her disability, she does brilliantly. “Doctors told us that her friends would eventually tail off but Fiona’s haven’t . They keep in contact with her and visit when they can. “People have shown us great kindness over the years in so many ways and this means a lot, helping us immensely. We don’t know what the future will hold for Fiona but we do know that whatever it is we will face it together.” There are , strokes in Scotland every year. Angela Macleod at the Stroke Association said: “Our latest research shows that by training and taking part in a Resolution Run you are helping to lower your stroke risk. “The funds raised by each runner means we can reach out to more stroke survivors and their families to offer the support that they may need to rebuild their lives.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnstrokeAyrAyr NewsPrestwickRunningCharity

title: record-numbers-in-the-frame-at-borders-arts-fair
story: DESPITE the weekends storms, over , visitors enjoyed this years Borders Art Fair - a  percent increase on last year.And more than pound, was spent on works by the regions leading contemporary artists throughout the event at Springwood Park.Over  artists, galleries and collectives took part, showcasing a selection of beautul works and inspiring and delighting visitors from the Borders and beyond.This yearrsquos Fair also included a series of talks by leading figures in Scotlandrsquos art world including VA Dundee director Philip Long and Scottish Gallery director Guy Peploe.The Fair organisers had also arranged a series of activities and workshops for children.And visitors were also able to enjoy artist-led workshops and demonstrations including figurative drawing and stone letter carving.Tours of the art and architecture of Borders historic houses, Mellerstain and Marchmont House, were full-booked throughout the weekend and an exhibition and print demonstration by the Royal Scottish Academy in Kelso Town Hall was also a popular addition to the  event.Borders Art Fair director Frances Fergusson told us: ldquoWersquore delighted that we were able to attract an additional , visitors to this yearrsquos event and are thrilled that the work on show was so well received."The aim of the Borders Art Fair is to engage and inspire people of all ages through amazing original work and itrsquos extremely rewarding to see their reactions as they enjoy the event and to be able to help support the incredibly talented artists who live and work in the Scottish Borders and surrounding areas.The Borders Art Fair is part funded by Awards for All, the Fallago Environment Fund, The Scottish Government and the European Scottish Borders LAG LEADER - programme.Event sponsors include Marchmont Farms, McInroy  Wood Investment Managers, Bruce Stevenson Insurance, Vivid Design Consultancy, Steven Rae Accountancy, Born in the Borders, Milne Graden holiday cottages and Airhouses Self Catering.

title: council-delays-decision-on-innerleithen-house-proposal
story: COUNCILLORS have delayed a decision on an Innerleithen manrsquos bid to build a house on one of the townrsquos many green spaces.Raymond Keddie, of Damside, Innerleithen, has previously had his initial plans to build a house on the corner of Maxwell Street and Damside refused by Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning department, but has now appealed to the local authorityrsquos local review body for a second hearing.However, councillors sitting on Scottish Borders Councilrsquos local review body, which met on Monday, delayed the proposal as they felt they needed more information on the previous use of the land.The plans for the currently empty site have been met with six objections from local residents, who highlight the loss of an historic green space and overdevelopment as chief amongst their concerns.Council officers initially rejected the proposals as they believe the loss of greenspace will have a ldquodetrimental impact on the townscape, and are still recommending the appeal is rejected.In a report to councillors, the councilrsquos planning officer Lucy Hoad writes: ldquoThe local community has raised concerns over the development of the site, regarding it to be an important historic open space contributing to the character and appearance of the Innerleithen conservation area.ldquoThe residents advised that a path used by the public ran diagonally through the site but has since been rerouted around the perimeter.ldquoFurther concerns raised by residents relate to the impact on services and residential amenity.ldquoThe applicant has submitted additional information to contend that outbuildings occupied the application site as some point in the past.ldquoHowever, more recent records indicate that the application site is regarded as being a long established open area that makes a positive contribution to the established character of the conservation area.ldquoThe proposed development at this site would be contrary to the local development plan in that development of this area of green space will have a detrimental impact on the townscape structure of the settlement and the special character and appearance of the conservation area.Mr Keddie has also submitted his own statement to the local review body highlighting the previous use of the land.It reads: ldquoA photo of Damside from circa  shows that prior to the opening of the Maxwell Street school this site had indeed contained a workshop, outbuildings and what looks like a dry stone wall.ldquoMs Hoad, in her report, dismisses this information as being historical, but that more recent records show this is a green space.ldquoI would like this evidence reviewed, as it is evident that this site was never, and never has been, defined a green space, other than it now forms a gap site following the demolition of the buildings to form Maxwell Street.ldquoIt has been stated on previous application refusals and Ms Hoadrsquos report that the land is of great importance to the community.ldquoI refute this statement on the basis that the erection of the fence on this area of land was necessitated by local residents allowing their pets to defecate on this land.ldquoI would propose that turning the site into a residence would be a better use of the space and ultimately better valued.Councillors have now instructed officers to author a detailed report on the historic uses of the land, and whether it qualies as green space under Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning policy.The local review body is due to meet again on April , when the application will be deliberated upon.

title: kith-and-kin-with-the-borders-family-history-society
story: Despite the lack of the publicity, the Eastern Borders History Gathering at the Volunteer Hall, Duns, on March  was a great success.Till Valley Archaeological Society, Ayton Local History Society, Dunse History Society, Bunkle and Preston History Group, Coldstream and District Local History Society and the University of Edinburghrsquos lsquoRecovering the Earliest English Language in Scotland: Evidence from place-namesrsquoproject all had interesting displays.There were around  people attending each talk mdash far surpassing the organisersrsquo expectations.The REELS project kicked off proceedings with a talk about Berwickshire place-names. Carole Hough demonstrated their new Berwickshire Place-Name Resource website which covers , place-names Simon Taylor, who, you may remember, talked about the subject at the  Borders Heritage Festival event in Coldstream, talked about their first Berwickshire place-name volume which will cover  parishes in the county, and Eila Williamson talked about literary references to places in Berwickshire: David Hume wrote about Godscroft , Sybilrsquos Well near Ladykirk is mentioned in Sir Walter Scottrsquos Marmion, Tibbie Fowlerrsquos Glen and Cottage are mentioned in Wilsonrsquos Tales of the Borders and no doubt there are lots more examples. Diane Hunter talked, with slides, about the Stobs Camp project. She said that the prisoner-of-war records were destroyed in the Blitz. She discussed what theyrsquove achieved, including rebuilding a memorial to the  POWs that died at Stobs and mentioned that theyrsquore looking for the huts and equipment, sold off after the war, and that they would like to hear from anyone that has a piece or knows where a hut is. One of the audience mentioned that Stobs Camp was used for motor-racing and learning to drive in the s.David Connolly told us about the lsquoskills passportrsquo ndash a little book in which your archaeological skills can be recorded and validated. Irsquom not convinced that it would be useful for anyone other than non-graduates under  but his British Archaeological Jobs and Resources website, www.bajr.org, seems useful for everyone especially for the  guides that can be downloaded for free. He did make a good point, however, that community-led archaeological projects need to be funded and funders expect organisers to specy outcomes, some of which could be trained volunteers and the skills passport could be used as evidence of those skills acquisitions. Lastly, Chris Bowles, the regional archaeologist announced his new project, lsquoWhiteadder ndash the Historic Heart of the Lammermuirsrsquo. This project which is expected to start in April will run for two years and a major deliverable is a heritage trail for walkers and drivers, from Garvald to Duns, taking in eight sites, four of which are prehistoric. Other outcomes are likely to explore Cockburn Law, the Friarrsquos Nose, Bunkle Castle, Gamelshiel Castle, Penshiel Grange, Whitecastle Hill among others and therersquoll be a website, an app, and leaflets discussing the sites and the heritage.The project will be looking for a iety of volunteers doing archaeology as well as desk-based researchyoursquore interested, email Chris at archaeology@scotborders.gov.uk or ring him at the Council.Peter Munro

title: 97-percent-of-poll-votes-against-great-tapestry-centre
story: AN online poll of more than , Borderers has ed an overwhelming rejection of the Great Tapestry of Scotland plans for Galashiels.Organisers of the Jetharts Here Facebook page conducted the month-long survey after a growing discontent over the proposals.Of the , online voters,  percentbelieved the project was a waste of money.Steven Somerville runs the Jetharts Here Facebook page. He told us: "We dont usually get involved in politics or anything like that but nobody I knew was in favour of all this money being spent on the Tapestry building, so we put it out to the followers of our page just to find out exactly what the feeling was."We have over , people on our page - not all from Jedburgh - and around one-in-four of them had a vote."There has been a growing discontent for a while and this vote shows just how strong the feeling is against the Tapestry."Scottish Borders Council initially planned to create a visitor centre close to the Borders Railway terminus at Tweedbank for the Great Tapestry of Scotland.But strong opposition from across the Borders led to a fresh study identying Galashiels as a preferred option.As well as a new visitor centre being built on the site of the former Poundstretcher store, the towns former Post Office will be brought back to le as part of the complex.The local authority has secured pound. million from the Scottish governments Borders Railway Blueprint towards the pound. million centre.A further pound, of central government money is also propping up the project.And the project has allowed further funding to come into the area for connected regeneration schemes.Independent consultants believe more than , will come through the doors during the first year of opening.And numbers will swell to a regular , per year over the next decade.The centre is also expected to create  jobs when it opens late next year.Mr Somerville added: "Some people have made valid points in support of the Tapestry but for the most part the feeling is that its a waste of money - money that could be better spent where."Although close to half of the cost is being met from ious pots at Holyrood, Scottish Borders Council is having to borrow pound. million to meet its share.Councillor Mark Rowley, the local authority spokesman for business and economic development, said: ldquoThe Great Tapestry of Scotland visitor attraction is seen as the catalyst for regeneration."Set to open in , it will have a range of facilities for visitors and the community to enjoy including interactive displays and audio guides, changing exhibitions, education activities, a gt shop, cafeacute with seasonal and local produce and a programme of events for all ages.ldquoHeritage and culture experts predict the centre will attract over , people to Galashiels each year, as well as create  new jobs at the facility.ldquoIn addition, almost pound, of extra spending per year is predicted for the local economy, providing , extra visits to complementary attractions, supporting a further  jobs.ldquoThere will also be jobs created during construction of the facility amongst other community benefits.ldquoWe are currently engaging with contractors on the building of the visitor centre, with construction scheduled to begin in coming months.

title: food-for-thought-as-emergency-parcel-demand-drops-in-selkirk
story: ORGANISERS of Selkirk Foodbank admit they are baffled by a recent downturn in customers.While the rest of the country has witnessed increases in the need for emergency food parcels, mainly due to changes in benefits, the Selkirk volunteers have seen demand drop over the past  months.Peter Birney from Selkirk Foodbank hopes a forthcoming Open Day will encourage anyone in need of help to come forward.He told us: "Our numbers havent increased like they have where -anything we are down slightly on a year ago."That can be seen as a good thing, but we fear that there are people out there who need help and dont know we are here."We have a steady amount of referrals from social work, health and third-sector organisations as well as the churches, but we hope to reach out to even more people who need help."Just last year the Trussell Trust, who organise and manage  foodbanks across the country, reported a  percent increase in demand during   from the previous year.And other locally-run foodbanks in the Borders have also seen demand rise in recent years.Selkirk Foodbank was supplying up to a dozen parcels each week at the start of .But the volunteers currently distribute between half a dozen and ten most weeks since the turn of the year.All school pupils in the town have now been given leaflets promoting the Open Day.And posters are also being displayed around Selkirk.Mr Birney hopes the Open Day at the Catholic Church Hall on Friday, April  will lead to more volunteers coming forward as well as raising awareness of the service.He added: "People can find out how foodbanks operate and how they can become involved - everything from donating items, making referrals to volunteering."We will have food sampling and refreshments throughout the open day and we will have a warm welcome for everyone."The Selkirk Foodbank Open Day on Friday, April  runs from am to pm.

title: 26-year-old-denies-kicking-new-mum-in-stomach

title: passengers-facing-further-disruption-on-borders-railway
story: PASSENGERS on the Borders Railway are facing further disruption today.All services to Edinburgh have been affected, due to a signalling fault at Haymarket Station.And commuters are being warned trains are not currently running to the usual timetable.A spokesperson for ScotRail said: "Trains which are currently on the line will take passengers to their destination."But there could be further disruption later as engineers work on the signalling fault at Haymarket."The problem comes after dozens were left stranded in the capital on Sunday evening after five of the scheduled seven trains to Tweedbank were cancelled.And passengers are being urged to check social media and the ScotRailwebsite before travelling.We will bring you updates when we get them.

title: glenternie-stars-in-holywood-producers-new-ghost-film
story: A REMOTE house in the Borders is starring in a Hollywood producers new short film.Glenternie House, in the Manor Valley, provides the eerie location for Gavin Laings comedy-horror The Hauntening.The -minute short film, which is due for screenings at film festivals around the world this year, follows an amateur ghost hunter who invites a world-famous medium to help her investigate a spooky old house she believes to be haunted.For Gavin, who who splits his time between Edinburgh and LA, Glenternie provided the perfect backdrop for his -minute movie.He said: "When making any film, location plays a vital role - but in The Hauntening, the manor is almost a character itself."We were incredibly lucky to find Glenternie House."Not only did it look great on camera, it was also a beautul location to spend a week filming with the incredible cast and crew.ldquoScotland has so much to offer filmmakers, with beautul scenery and historic locations. Were fortunate to have so many wonderful spots on our doorstep.Gavin, who is originally from Edinburgh, studied Digital Film and Television from the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland.His graduation short film, My First Spellbook, which he wrote and directed, won Best Undergraduate Fiction at the Royal Television Society Scotland Awards , Best Comedy at the Limelight Film Awards , and was nominated for Best Student Drama at the Celtic Media Festival .It received its world premiere at the Chicago International Childrenrsquos Film Festival in  and has continued a sustained run in international film festivals ever since, including screenings at the childrenrsquos section of the Toronto International Film Festival in , and most recently at the International Childrenrsquos Media Centerrsquos ICFilmFest in , where it won the Best of the Fest Award.Gavin went on to study on the prestigious Peter Stark Producing Program at the University of Southern Calorniarsquos School of Cinematic Arts.His first short film at USC,Spring Forward, won The Celebration of Comedy Award at the Jack Oakie Comedy Festival in .During his final year of study, Gavin also worked in Creative Development at Sony Pictures Animation.Since graduating in May , Gavin secured a position at The Gotham Group, a management and production company that specializes in the family and animation space.As well as producing and directing The Hauntening, Gavin was also co-writer.The Hauntening stars Helen MacFarlane as Joan, Charles Donnelly as Raymond and Rachel Breadner as Miss Burrows.Glenternie House, which dates back to , sits around four miles from Peebles.

title: play-your-part-in-the-latest-chapter-at-smails
story: A VOLUNTEER drop-in day has been arranged at one of the regions most-treasured visitor attractions this weekend.On Sunday there will be an opportunity to become part of the latest chapter at Robert Smailrsquos Printing Works in Innerleithen.The drop-in from noon to pm is for anyone interested in getting involved in bringing this unique National Trust propertyrsquos story to le for visitors.The team will be on-hand to explain the benefits of volunteering for the charity that protects Scotlandrsquos national and natural treasures, and the opportunities available this visitor season.Ted McKie, a volunteer at Robert Smailrsquos since , said: ldquoIt has been great to make new friends and to have the opportunity to meet people from dferent backgrounds and visitors from all over the world."I feel proud to play my part in helping to preserve a unique piece of industrial heritage and would encourage anyone with an interest in local history, the print industry or people with free time on their hands to get involved.For more than  years, Smails served the people of Innerleithen in all their printing and stationery needs.From dance cards to birthday cards, newspapers to invitations ndash the people of Innerleithen and Peeblesshire were well-served.Now, the works is looking for enthusiastic people to join the team by becoming volunteers as it approaches the start of a new season.In the care of the National Trust for Scotland, the printing works are looking for support in a range of roles including tour guiding, working in the gt shop and maintaining the courtyard garden.The print works, whose Edwardian shop front is currently being restored, are open to the public from April to October for guided tours around the machine room, office, paper store and caseroom where volunteers can help to tell the stories of the Smailrsquos family business which was first established in .Robert Smailrsquos Printing Works opens on Monday, April  through to Monday, October  - Mondays, Fridays and Saturdays am to pm, and on Sundays pm to pm.

title: scottish-strongmen-set-for-jed-showdown
story: SCOTLANDrsquoS finest strongmen are set to descend upon Jedburgh as they battle to be declared Scotlandrsquos Strongest Man.Jed Forest Rugby Football Club will host the event on Saturday, June .Audiences will be able to watch competitors attempt five gruelling feats of strength as they bid for strongman glory and a place at the Channel  UK Strongest Man Final.Competitors such as Paul lsquoBad Boyrsquo Benton and rising star Louis Jack will provide stern opposition for Kelsorsquos Celtic warrior, Jas Hastie.Only  tickets are available, with prices starting at pound for adults and pound for children under .

title: tourist-information-screens-to-be-taken-down-across-the-borders
story: ELECTRONIC tourist information boards are to be removed from the region next month.Scottish Borders Council bosses have confirmed the interactive screens in Melrose, Tweedbank, Stow and Hawick will be taken down "following a number of issues".The subject was brought up at Wednesdays meeting of Melrose Community Council.The towns board, which is located in Market Square, was erected back in .At the time, community councillors expressed their concerns over the two-metre high gizmo, which took several weeks to connect up to the wi-fi network.And when it was fixed, it was criticised for being in the wrong place and for not showing enough local information.Vice chairwoman of the community council said in : "There seems to be an awful lot on it, apart from Melrose."We want to show visitors what is on offer here, not other towns."Surely this has been constructed in the wrong place. Its been a great deal of trouble at a great deal of expense."This box has been put right in the middle of the most photographic part of town."However Scottish Borders Council have now decided to remove the boards from four Borders communities.A spokesperson told us: ldquoFollowing a number of issues with its visitor information screens the council has taken the decision to terminate its contract with the current provider."As a result the remaining screens in Hawick, Stow, Melrose and Tweedbank will be removed.ldquoThe council is investigating a range of options, including replacement interactive screens and alternate provision.

title: gerda-to-lead-celebrations-of-legendary-filmmaker
story: AN award-winning local actress will be a major player in honouring film-maker Margaret Tait at this years Alchemy Festival.BAFTA-winning actress Gerda Stevenson, who is most notably known for her role as Murrenrsquos mother in Braveheart, is also a director and writer.Gerda, who lives in West Linton, is set to give a keynote talk on Tait and lead the popular Film Walk at this yearrsquos Alchemy Film and Moving Image Festival in May.And as part of the celebration of the centenary of the Scottish filmmaker and poet, known as the MT, Stevenson has also been specially commissioned to write a new poem inspired by Taitrsquos work.Gerda won a Scottish BAFTA for her appearance in Margaret Taitrsquos only feature film Blue Black Permanent.It was the first feature film made by a Scottish woman and continues to inspire young female filmmakers to this day.In , Gerda showed off another of her many talents as she was nominated for the MG Alba Scots Traditional Awards in the Scots Singer of the Year category.Within the same year, she was nominated as one the Saltire Societyrsquos Outstanding Women of Scotland.Alchemy Film and Moving Image Festival has been running in Hawick since being established in . The festival has increased in popularity since the beginning and last year they screened  films from  dferent countries.Michael Pattison, Creative Director of Alchemy said: ldquoWe are delighted that Gerda Stevenson will join us for the first MT event in The Borders.ldquoHer special relationship with Margaret Tait, developed as they worked together on Blue Black Permanent, gives her a very particular insight into Taitrsquos le and work.ldquoWe look forward to Gerdarsquos contribution to this yearrsquos festival, especially the poem which she is writing specially for us.The concluding event of the festival, the annual Film Walk, will be led by Gerda and will end in a special film screening at a pop-up cinema.In celebration of MT, this yearrsquos film will be one of her masterpieces Orquil Burn.And Stevensonrsquos specially commissioned poem will be a response to the rsquos film.The full  Alchemy programme, which runs in Hawick from May  to , will be announced on April .

title: oxton-scout-earns-leadership-accolade
story: AN Oxton Scout has been presented with a prestigious honour at the Scottish Parliament.Josh Beaumont, a member of the Lauderdale Scout Group, earned the Explorer Scout Young Leader Belt.The -year-old is only the second Lauderdale Scout to earn the Young Leader belt, mirroring his older sister Abbeyrsquos efforts when she received the award three years ago.His achievement was recognised by Lauderdale MSP Christine Grahame, who presented Josh with his belt during a recent visit to Holyrood with the Lauderdale Scout Group.ldquoI was delighted to be interrogated by Lauderdale Explorer Scout Group at Parliament recently, said Ms Grahame.ldquoNot only to meet these impressive young people but to present to Josh his well-deserved and hard-earned award of his Young Leader belt.ldquoI am sure Joshrsquos achievement will inspire others to follow in his footsteps.The Explorer Scout Young Leader Scheme is an opportunity for Scouts to make a positive impact in their communities and to fulfil the service elements of many of the top awards in Scouting.Josh said: ldquoI am really happy to get my Young Leader belt.ldquoI really enjoy working with the younger sections in the Scout Group.ldquoEarning my belt was not easy but it helped me to learn what makes a good leader.

title: borders-author-brings-the-stage-to-the-page
story: A BORDERS author has released a mammoth work focusing on the history of British theatre.Spanning two volumes, and almost , pages, An Illustrated History of British Theatre and Performance uncovers , years of theatre history, from Roman Britain to the present day.Doctor Robert Leach, who has lived in Selkirk since , has a long association with the world of theatre and performing arts.A former lecturer in English Literature at The University of Edinburgh, Dr Leach has acted in the United States of America and even directed theatre productions in Moscow, and his new books draw on this extensive experience and knowledge.Dr Leach told The Border : ldquoI have spent my le shuttling between active theatre work and academic le, so I suppose the book marries these two careers.ldquoIm retired now and have lots of hours to fill - hence the books!Whereas most writers who have considered the history of theatre have confined themselves to describing events in Londonrsquos west end, Dr Leach is keen to highlight the historical roles played by a erse array of characters from across the country.The Borders, in fact, has its own claim to fame in the storied history of British theatre.ldquoWhen the Scottish Enlightenment challenged a superstitious kirk, pivotal to the argument was a play by a Borderer - The Tragedy of Douglas by John Home, Dr Leach explained.Home, born in Ancrum, is immortalised on the Scott Monument in Edinburgh.The Bordersrsquo role in live theatre and performance is not solely the preserve of the history books, however, and the region is home to numerous thriving amateur dramatic societies and theatrical ventures.Dr Leach believes the theatre still has an important role to play in society.He said: ldquoIn this age of screens, recordings and digital communication of all sorts, the live theatre can reach parts no other art form can.ldquoI am therefore very excited by the new Pub Theatre which makes its debut at the County Hotel in Selkirk.ldquoLong may it flourish!An Illustrated History of British Theatre and Performance, published by Routledge, is available now, priced at pound per volume.

title: search-is-on-to-find-everton-goalkeepers-grave
story: A HERITAGE group associated with Everton Football Club is trying to locate the grave of the goalkeeper who helped them win their first ever Championship.And they believe it could be in the Scottish Borders.Everton Heritage Society has already erected headstones for two other players from north of the Border, Andrew Hannah and Sandy Young, who were buried in unmarked graves.They now want to do the same for David Jardine, who became the Merseyside clubs first keeper to everplay at Goodison Park in .The son of a stonemason from Dumfriesshire ed to Scotland following his football career, living in the Lanarkshire village of Crawford at the start of the twentieth century.His we, Sarah, died after the family moved to a house near Elvanfoot in .They had two sons - John and Robert - and it was from emigration papers from eldest son, Robert, when arriving back from South Africa in the s that it is known David Jardine had retired to a cottage at Causewayend between Biggar and Coulter.Evertons first Goodison Park and Championship-winning goalkeeper died on March ,  at the cottage just outside Biggar.But where he is buried has become a mystery.Tony Onslow from Everton Heritage Society told us: "The obvious place for David to be buried is with his we at Elvanfoot Church but there is no record of him there."We have exhausted every option around South Lanarkshire and also where Davids parents and siblings are buried at Applegarth in Dumfriesshire."There is a chance he was cremated but, again, we can find no record."Everton Heritage Society undertake one or two of these research projects every year with the aim of re-dedicating the grave with a headstone featuring the club crest."David Jardine was born on December , , at Templand in Dumfriesshire.Following school he served his apprenticeship as a tailor but it was while playing as goalkeeper for Mid-Annandale that he attracted attention.In March , at the age of , he accepted a professional contract from English Football Alliance club, Bootle.It was in a game against Merseyside rivals Everton on April ,  that Jardine grabbed the headlines as he helped Bootle pull off a major - shock.The match report in the Football Field periodical stated: "The young Scot between the sticks punched, kicked and caught the ball with great agility."He threw himself down upon the ball in a manner which even the heartbroken Evertonians could not forebear to cheer."Jardine also helped Bootle to lt the Liverpool Senior Cup in his first season.The following November he signed for Everton and made his debut in a - victory over Blackburn Rovers as they went on to win their first ever Football League championship.,params: .pushJardine shared shared goalkeeping duties during   as Everton saw out their final season playing at Anfield.And he was between the posts in the clubs very first league game at the new Goodison Park against Nottingham Forest on September , .Jardine - having played a total of  games for Everton - left Merseyside at the end of the season and signed for Lancashire club Nelson.Although he helped his new team win the Lancashire League, he was toto Scotland and marry Sarah Smith in .Jardine also ed to tailoring - although he did briefly help Wrexham win the Welsh FA Cup in .Mr Onslow added: "We are fairly sure hes not buried anywhere in South Lanarkshire as the council has helped us with our research."We are hoping that there will be descendants of David Jardine still living in the area who can help us."The Everton Heritage Society has already erected two headstones in Scotland.Last year they rededicated the grave of Andrew Hannah at Kilbowie Cemetery in Clydebank.Hannah, who was a Scottish international, is the only footballer to ever captain both Everton and Liverpool.And in  they also erected a stone for Sandy Young, who scored the FA Cup final winning goal against Newcastle in , at Seafield Cemetery in Edinburgh.Civic and religious authorities have records of who is buried where, but researching historic archives can be laborious and often fruitless.Scottish Borders Council has conducted an initial check, after we contacted them, and officers have agreed to carry out a more in-depth investigation of cemeteries around Broughton and up to the South Lanarkshire boundary in the coming weeks.A spokesperson told us: ldquoWe have begun checking our records to seeDavid Jardinersquos unmarked grave is situated in the Borders.Anyone who can help the Everton Heritage Society track down David Jardines grave can contact Mr Onslow at themanfromthehillcountry@hotmail

title: scotrail-in-last-chance-saloon-following-borders-railway-performance
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has warned ScotRail it is in ldquothe last chance saloon following its recent performance.The First Minister said the Dutch-owned Abellio, which has held the -year franchise to run most of the countryrsquos trains since , could be stripped of the dealit fails to improve.Dozens of Borders Railway passengers were left stranded in the capital last Sunday evening after five of the scheduled seven trains to Tweedbank were cancelled.And commuters faced further disruption throughout the week ndash due to signalling problems and staff shortages.At First Ministers Questions on Thursday, Borders MSP Christine Grahame asked Ms Sturgeon whether, in light of ldquotravel chaos on the line, she considered the ScotRail franchise continued to be ldquosustainable.Ms Sturgeon said she was disappointed passengers faced an ldquounacceptable number of cancellations due to staff training, and said ScotRail was working on a remedial plan.Ms Grahame told her the cancellations had continued since Sunday.She said: ldquoThe plan might be delivered. But that doesnrsquot deliver trains. Plans donrsquot drive trains. Isnrsquot it time that the Scottish Government told ScotRail-Abellio itrsquos in the last chance saloon  I certainly think so, and so do my constituents.The question was greeted with applause from Labour MSPs who want Abellio to be stripped of the ScotRail franchise.,params: .pushMs Sturgeon said: ldquoScotRail should treat a remedial plan very much as a last chance saloon. Thatrsquos the very nature of it. ScotRail has been left in doubt that its recent levels of performance, particularly in the Borders and Fe have been completely unacceptable.ldquoWersquove used contractual mechanisms contained with the franchise agreement to require the remedial plan, and ScotRail will publish its performance remedial plan on its website shortly.ldquoThe commitments in the plan have been contracted as a remedial agreement. In the event ScotRail does not achieve improved performance or fails to deliver on its contractual commitments, it does of course run the risk of having the franchise terminated early.Tory MSP Rachael Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, read a letter from a constituent who said they were ldquogenuinely surprised when the Borders service was on time, and problems caused ldquosignicant stress and anxiety because of lateness at work and fines for collecting their child from nursery.She said hundreds of commuters were ldquoexperiencing transport hell and urged Ms Sturgeon to intervene and personally oversee the remedial plan.However, Ms Sturgeon made it clear she would not intervene.She said: ldquoThe transport secretary will oversee that, because it is part of his responsibilities. However, as First Minister, I, too, will obviously retain a very close interest in the matter.A ScotRail spokesperson said: ldquoEveryone at ScotRail is working flat out to deliver the quality of service that our customers expect and deserve.ldquoOur most recent period of performance is also very encouraging and shows that the investment we are making in Scotlandrsquos Railway is delivering signicant improvements.ldquoWe know there are still areas where we need to improve and we will work closely with Transport Scotland to deliver those improvements.

title: celebrity-support-for-25th-borders-walking-festival
story: TICKETS for the th Scottish Borders Walking Festival, a week-long event held in Selkirk and the Ettrick and Yarrow valleys from September , are set to go on sale later this month ndash and a famous face has signed on to lend support.This yearrsquos event will be kicked off by one of Scotlandrsquos top outdoor writers, and presenter of the BBC Adventure Show, Cameron McNeish.McNeish, who will appear at the festivalrsquos opening night celebrations, was editor of The Great Outdoors magazine for twenty years and still writes regular columns in Scots Magazine, Campervan Magazine, the Herald and for online magazine www.walkhighlands.His most recent best-selling book, Therersquos Always the Hills, with foreword written by Sam Heughan, star of Outlander and a walking enthusiast, won the  lsquoThe Great Outdoorsrsquo Magazine Book of the Year award.Cameron will be giving a presentation on his book with a signing afterwards, while the evening will also see music from local performers Selkirk Silver Band and the Clarsach Duo, Madalaine Cross and Charlotte Tuckwood.This yearrsquos festival will see a total of  guided countryside walks of ied s, taking in routes across the Selkirk, Ettrick and Yarrow Valley areas - from the Southern Upland Way, the Grey Marersquos Tail Waterfall and the Ring orsquo the Loch to the famous Three Brethren and many more.There will be seven daily walks led by local experts and enthusiasts, including a James Hogg Poetry walk in Ettrick, a stroll with a Bowhill Estate Ranger and a tour around the historic Ettrickbridge, led by village residents.The Scottish Borders Walking Festival began in , making it the longest walking festival of its kind in Scotland.The event is organised and run by volunteers for the benefit of the local community and visiting walkers.Keith Robeson, Senior Ranger at Scottish Borders Council, who has been involved since the very beginning, said: ldquoThe Borders really lends itself to walking and the festival moves around dferent towns every year, so gives walkers plenty iety, while being held in September gives us an excellent chance of good weather in Scotland.Sue Briggs, Chair of the Festival Steering Group, added: ldquoWersquore really lucky to have the Selkirk Farmersrsquo Market and the Yarrow Show on during our festival week and the town will also be decorated with weird and wonderful hats as part of the Souter Stormer Yarn Bombers HatFest competition ndash Border Bunnets.ldquoIt is going to be a brilliant atmosphere.Keen hikers will be able to secure tickets for from midnight on March  by visiting www.borderswalking.

title: 25-year-old-defies-ban-by-turning-up-exs-work-in-gala
story: A JEDBURGH man has admitted breaching a non-harassment order involving his former partner.Nathan Gillie pleaded guilty to the offence which happened at her place of employment in Bank Street, Galashiels, on February .Jedburgh Sherf Court was told that the -year-old asked a friend to go into a hairdressing salon to request that she came outside to speak to him.He also sent  messages to her through a fake Facebook profile he had set up under the name of Steven Smith and turned up at her home in Howdenburn Court, Jedburgh, at .am shouting: "I know you have someone in there."Gillie of Bongate, told police has former partner was "playing mind games with him" and that she had been contacting him looking for lts.But procurator fiscal Graham Fraser countered: "She is suffering from anxiety because of his behaviour and fears what he will do next and she deserves protection."Sherf Donald Ferguson said it appeared to be a "fragrant disregard" of the court order but asked the Crown to investigate on whether the former partner had been contacting Gillie for when the case next calls on April .Sentence has been deferred for a Caledonian Mens Programme assessment.

title: mp-invites-scotrail-boss-to-galashiels-public-meeting
story: FOLLOWING another week of misery for commuters on the Borders Railway, MP John Lamont has invited the managing director of Scotrail, Alex Hynes, to a public meeting in Galashiels next month.Disruption on the Tweedbank to Edinburgh line has been an ongoing issue, with reports of overcrowding, cancellations and late trains now an almost daily occurrence.After receiving a huge number of complaints from constituents, a public meeting is now being arranged in April to give commuters the opportunity to grill Scotrail over their recent failures.Mr Lamont, who is currently awaiting a response from ScotRail to this invitation, said: ldquoCancellations and overcrowding on the Borders Railway has now become such a problem that people are being put off using the train and are ing to their cars.ldquoAs well as the disruption that is being caused to peoplersquos lives I am also concerned these issues are undermining the case to have the line extended to Hawick and Newcastleton.ldquoI am far from convinced that Scotrail, or the Scottish Government for that matter, understand the level of frustration commuters are feeling in the Borders.ldquoThe line appears to be an afterthought with the Borders route being understaffed and stock being pulled from the Borders to make sure the central belt is getting a good service.ldquoI have no doubt that local people will make their feelings clear next month.Details of the date and venue will be published as soon as they are confirmed.

title: las-vegas-comes-to-the-volunteer-hall
story: AFTER three years of sell-out stage shows, Scotlandrsquos top nine-piece showband, Spatz  Co, launched their lsquoOne Night in Las Vegasrsquo tour in Galashiels earlier this month.The show offered a taste of the glitz and glamour from the famous entertainment capital of the world.From swing to blues, soul to Latin, and jazz to pop, their repertoire included songs made famous by stars such as Frank Sinatra, Elvis Presley, Barry Manilow, Chuck Berry, Paul Simon and Eric Clapton. Galashiels fans also enjoyed the popular Glen Miller lsquoBig Bandrsquo sound.Olly Robertson from organisers Live Borders told us: "We are very privileged to have hosted the debut show of the talented multi-instrumentalist band Spatz  Co."Their show was so ied, offering something for everyone, and all performed with the highest skill by musicians from around Scotland."The newly-refurbished Volunteer Hall was the perfect venue to host lsquoOne Night in Las Vegasrsquo, and we are happy to be bringing the highest quality music to the Borders.For further information on live events taking place at Live Bordersrsquo venues, visit www.liveborders.org.uk

title: lamont-calls-for-mobile-operators-to-provide-rural-roaming
story: LOCAL MP John Lamont is backing proposals which would require mobile operators to cooperate to implement roaming in rural parts of the UK.As part of a consultation on telecommunications the UK Government has called on Ofcom to review the possibility of allowing consumers to access other operators when they do not get coverage from their own operator.It forms part of the UK Governmentrsquos commitment to extend mobile coverage to  percent of the UK by .Recent Ofcom figures show that only  percent of Scotlandrsquos landmass has coverage from an operator and only  percent has good G coverage from all operators.Despite this dearth of G coverage, major UK network operators are already committing to rolling out G services in  and EE has announced the first sixteen UK cities to receive G coverage.Lamont, who has repeatedly called for more to be done to improve mobile signal in the Borders, has now joined with fellow MPs representing rural constituencies to write to the Department for Culture, Media and Sport, urging them to improve the existing service.He said: ldquoA lack of mobile phone signal is a huge source of frustration for many communities in the Borders.ldquoLike the problems with broadband, having a decent mobile signal is holding businesses back and is really unfair for consumers who are paying the same as everyone  for an inferior service.ldquoThese proposals have the potential to vastly improve mobile signal in the Borders and they have already been endorsed by Ofcom as effective.ldquoThat is why I am calling on the UK Government to require mobile networks to implement mobile roaming as soon as possible.

title: estate-agents-bring-transport-interchange-close-to-capacity
story: A LONG established firm of solicitor estate agents is the latest tennants to move into the Galashiels Interchange.Cullen Kilshaw, who have nine offices across the central Borders, will let the majority of the second floor including the Waverley Chambers.The prominent Transport Interchange building was constructed in  to coincide with the arrival of the Borders Railway.And with this latest move is  percent full with small to medium sized businesses.Cullen Kilshaw senior partner David Kilshaw is delighted to create a central hub for his business.He said: "We are delighted to be moving into the Interchange later this spring."As the largest solicitor estate agency in the Borders we have offices extending from Peebles in the west through central Borders across to Jedburgh, Hawick and Kelso."This gives us a welcome opportunity to bring together some of our core services in what is a hugely impressive piece of modern architecture.Cullen Kilshawrsquos move to the Interchange follows a rapid expansion of the practice over the last five years with the number of staff increasing to , a wider range of available services and new offices opening up in Selkirk, Hawick, Kelso and Jedburgh.While the firm will continue to have shop front offices in all of its seven existing town locations across the Borders, it is moving to a hub and spoke model with some of its core staff and support services coming together at the Interchange to share an ideal central location.The pound.million Galashiels Transport Interchange was opened in August  and was part funded by the European Regional Development Fund and delivered by Scottish Borders Councils development partner Hub South East Scotland and appointed contractor Morrison Construction.The facility has tourist information, bus and train real-time information and a railway ticket machine.There are also showers, Changing Places toilets, bike lockers to promote cycling and walking, and a cafe run by local firm Born in the Borders on the ground floor, with two additional floors of office space.The offices are let by local company Edwin Thompson.Commercial partner Simon Sanderson commented: ldquoThe Transport Interchange is a prominent building for the Borders, aiding both businesses and visitors alike."Wersquore pleased to have Cullen Kilshaw as new tenants of Waverley Chambers filling the majority of the second floor of the high quality suites."This brings occupancy levels at Waverley Chambers up to  percent highlighting the strong location and transport links."The final unit available is well suited to firms looking to relocate to a modern and contemporary office environment with travel links throughout the Borders and Edinburgh.

title: kith-and-kin-in-association-with-the-borders-family-history-society
story: Our next talk is this Sunday, March , when the title of Isabel Gordonrsquos talk is lsquoSmallpox Across the Class Dividersquo.Isabel Gordon is a good speaker and Irsquove heard a bit of her talk before and it was fascinating. Lots of lives were affected by smallpox, even in Scotland, so your own family history might have been impacted, too. I suspect wersquoll have a larger audience than usual, so come early to get a good seat. The talk is at St. Peterrsquos Church Hall, Parsonage Road, Galashiels, TD HS . Itrsquos very easy to get to, with some parking available in the grounds or on nearby roads, and therersquos a very convenient bus stop ndash just ask for the St Peters Schoolbus stop. Doors open at pm the talk begins at .pm.Well have a range of family history publications available to buy, and therersquoll be light refreshments available after the talk. If you have a problem with your family history, please discuss it with one of our volunteers.In last weekrsquos article, I mentioned the new Berwickshire Place-Name Resource website but I didnrsquot have space to review it. The new website, berwickshire-placenames.glasgow.ac.uk, includes every Berwickshire place-name found on the Ordnance Survey :, Landranger map, and can be searched in dferent ways. The home page offers several dferent tools but the main ones are Browse Place-Names, Element Glossary and Advanced Search. I suspect that for most people, the Browse Place-Names mechanism will be the most useful. It enables you to find a place-name alphabetically or on a map. Taking the evocatively-sounding name, lsquoFriarrsquos Nosersquo, which is one of the sites to be explored by Chris Bowlesrsquo archaeology project, lsquoWhiteadder ndash the Historic Heart of the Lammermuirsrsquo, what does the website tell us Clicking on Browse Place-Names takes me to an alphabet that shows how many records there are for each letter. A click on lsquoFrsquo shows me a new page from which I can select lsquoFriarrsquos Nosersquo. It also shows the parish name, map references and altitude. I can choose to view the record or show its location on a map. However, even the View Record button, displays a detailed map with the location, general information and therersquos a button to see more details or to see historical forms of the name. lsquoMore detailsrsquo gives the etymology of the name which includes the fact that the lsquoNosersquo element is a corruption of lsquoNessrsquo. The historical forms have been Freris Neis,  Frierneise,  Freereniss or Freernise,  Friers know rig,  and Friars Nose in .The Element Glossary shows the elements of place-names, their meaning and the place-names in which they occur. It can be searched by languagefor those interested in the origins of place-names. The Advanced Search is worth a look as it can be used to search by parish, feature, altitude, current place-name or place-name element. Itrsquos a very interesting resource.Peter Munro
