title: the-voice-uk-holding-early-audition-in-haddington
story: The popular primetime STV programme has enlisted the help of Lamp House Music for the early stages of casting for next yearrsquos series.Over the coming weeks, a team from The Voice UK is travelling across the country scouting for singers and musicians and approached Lamp House Music to help them in their search due to its work with young musical talent in East Lothian.Roz Maguire, of Haddington-based Lamp House Music, said: ldquoWe come across so many talented vocalists and musicians through Lamp House Music that we are happy to be helping The Voice UK in their search.ldquoItrsquos a y audition process ndash but wersquore keeping our fingers crossed that someone local will make it all the way through to the actual TV show.ldquoSadly, I donrsquot think Tom Jones will be joining us at this stage!For first auditions, participants need to prepare one or two songs with a backing track or musical instrument, for an audition lasting no more than  minutes.All participants must be aged  or over by October  and to sign up for an audition, which must be reserved in advance, email roz@lamphousemusic or call  .Auditions take place in Haddington on Monday, between pm and pm.

title: east-lothian-council-asbos-and-immorality
story: The tough new measures also give East Lothian Council the right to suspend applicants for up to three yearsthey have been anti-social neighbours, received a jail term for a crime committed locally or in their home, or built up rent arrears.Among the offences which are now punishable by being taken off the waiting list for a period of time are harassment andthe applicant ldquohas been convicted of using a house for immoral or illegal purposes.That could include activity such as drug use, drug dealing or operating a brothel from the property.Applicants who refuse two ldquoreasonable offers of housing will also be suspended for  months.The powers are part of a new Housing Allocation Policy which has been approved by the councilrsquos cabinet.It follows consultation with council tenants and staff, who were asked for their views on the current points system and possibility of suspensions.On the whole, they backed many of the changes overwhelmingly, including action against applicants deemed to break the rules.Other key changes to the policy will see an increase in overcrowding points for families with a boy and girl sharing a room when one is over  years old.Applicants who own property and people who live with them who are property owners will also be taken into account under new powers approved by the Scottish Government.The new policy comes into effect from May .Councillor Jim Goodfellow, cabinet member for housing, said: ldquoConcerns have been expressed about overcrowding where a family has two children of dferent sex sharing a room, and many of our tenants will also be glad to see home ownership brought into it.ldquoChanges made ensure our policy is as fair as it can be, is up to date and is also in line with the Governmentrsquos homelessness legislation.And Councillor Willie Innes, council leader, said: ldquoThe allocations system will never meet everybodyrsquos approval there will be people who feel they are being disadvantaged and will see it as unfair.ldquoThe changes being brought forward will benefit the current system.

title: three-east-lothian-schools-in-top-100-based-on-percentage-achieving-five-or-more-highers

title: astonishing-level-of-dog-dirt-on-sports-pitches-in-tranent
story: Sports clubs are working alongside East Lothian Council in a bid to reduce the number of people failing to clear up after their pets.Three blackspots in the area have been identied ndash Polson Park, Meadowmill and Ross High playing fields ndash and Councillor Colin McGinn described the amount of dog fouling as ldquoastonishing.He said: ldquoWhat is currently happening is the rugby club and Tranent Colts, who use Ross High playing fields, they have to send out a group of coaches or officials to walk the pitches and clear up the mess before they start playing. Runners at Meadowmill, or even the cricket club, are having to go out and make sure the training areas are clean before they start.ldquoFolk want to just turn up and get fit or improve their wellbeing without having to resort to clearing up dog mess before any activity.ldquoIt is irresponsible and pretty uncaring from people.Mr McGinn, who lives in Tranent, visited Meadowmill alongside representatives from ious East Lothian Council departments, including environmental health.The councillor described the situation as ldquoa disgrace, with a campaign to be launched in the coming weeks.Adam Hook, head coach at Ross High RFC, agreed it was a major problem.He said: ldquoIt is really frustrating. You can imagine we are trying to get warmed up and someone stops playing after spotting dog mess on the pitch. Someone then has got to take time out to clear it up and it impacts the warm up or during the game.Mr Hook was keen to see more regular patrols carried out by dog wardens in an attempt to catch irresponsible pet owners.He added: ldquoThey should hit them in the pocket and seethey do it again.ldquoIt is just total laziness. I know lots of people with dogs that would never dream of doing it.Phil Purves, chairman of Tranent Colts, agreed that it was a problem which was getting worse.He told the Courier: ldquoIt is very frustrating.ldquo[Clearing dog fouling] is something we have done pretty much all the time we have coached but it is out of control now.ldquoWe had a game two weeks ago and had to clean up  piles off one pitch.The club has recently bought a dog fouling bin to be put near the playing fields in a bid to encourage owners to clean up after their pets.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe council has noted an increase in complaints about dog fouling in recent weeks, particularly within grass sports areas and school grounds.ldquoOptions are currently being considered as to how best to tackle this situation and will be communicated in due course. In the meantime, all dog owners are reminded of their legal and moral responsibility to clean up after their dog and dispose of the waste properly.

title: new-affordable-homes-in-ormiston-approved
story: The  new homes off the villagersquos Tynemount Road will be part of a larger development by Walker Homes. In total,  properties are being built at the site.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department gave the scheme the go-ahead last week, with  affordable houses and  flats to be built on the site.The housing will be a mix of council homes and mid-market rentals.Each of the new homes will be classed as affordable housing, with the  flats comprising of six semi-detached two-storey flatted buildings with two bedrooms, and four semi-detached two-storey flats with one bedroom in each.Ten of the houses will be semi-detached, with three terraced properties and two detached homes.Sixteen of the properties will have three bedrooms, with the remaining house containing two bedrooms.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe are delighted to be creating more affordable housing units in Ormiston.ldquoAt least  of these will be new council houses.ldquoWe are currently in discussion with another affordable housing provider to potentially deliver  of the units for mid-market rent, creating a mixed tenure development to meet the ied needs of our communities.Meanwhile, more than pound, will be split between the villagersquos primary school and Ross High School in Tranent to ensure that there is sufficient educational capacity to serve the housing.A sum of pound, will go towards Ormiston Primary School, with a further pound, going to the secondary school.Haddington and Lammermuir ward member Councillor Shamin Akhtar was delighted with the additional housing. She said: ldquoIt is good news that permission has been granted for  council houses and  affordable homes for rent in Ormiston.ldquoThese are much-needed homes and will be welcomed by the local community.

title: longniddry-schoolgirl-meets-nicola-sturgeon-over-bubbles-campaign
story: Ellie McIntyre champions Longniddry Primary Schoolrsquos Bubbles Beat Balloons campaign, which encourages people to blow eco-friendly bubbles as an alternative to releasing balloons at public celebrations or tribute events.The youngster wrote to First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, who invited the eight-year-old to the Scottish Parliament to discuss the scheme further.The P pupil received a letter from Ms Sturgeonrsquos office highlighting the importance of young people being involved in developing initiatives and taking them forward.Ellie, who lives in Tranent, said: ldquoIt was exciting to meet Nicola Sturgeon and she let me have a selfie with her.ldquoI was happy she was able to sign our pledge.The youngster was joined at Holyrood by her mum Pauline, as well as her class teacher Yvonne Hart.The group were given a tour of the building, before meeting Ms Sturgeon and sitting in at First Ministerrsquos Questions. Ellie took a framed campaign certicate and Ms Sturgeon signed the lsquoBubbles Beat Balloonsrsquo pledge.Miss Hart added: ldquoThe First Minister was clearly impressed by Ellie and was keen to sign our campaign.ldquoFor her to make time in her busy schedule like this was amazing!The environmental campaign was launched by the school, which is home to  pupils, last summer.After participating in a One Planet One Future project and watching the BBCrsquos Blue Planet  programme ndash which highlighted the devastating impact of plastic on wildle and nature ndash the pupils decided to take action.The children learnt that mass balloon releases were often used when celebrating events or for remembering loved ones. So they decided the much-loved childrenrsquos pastime of blowing bubbles was a much more environmentally friendly way of marking special events instead of polluting the planet with latex balloons.The initiative has already been backed by the Marine Conservation Society, as well as East Lothian Councilrsquos Countryside Ranger Service.Pupils at the school have delivered presentations to local community councillors while a number of local businesses and organisations have signed up to the Bubbles Beat Balloons pledge.The campaign was part of the schoolrsquos work towards achieving gold status as a Rights Respecting School. Longniddry is the only primary school in East Lothian to hold Gold Right Respecting Schools status.The UNICEF UK award recognises the schoolrsquos work embedding childrenrsquos rights in its policy, practices and culture.Sheona Skinner, headteacher, said: ldquoIrsquom incredibly proud of Ellie using her pupil voice to continue our schoolrsquos campaign. Having the First Ministerrsquos support has widened awareness of the initiative and will hopefully encourage more people to become involved. It was a special occasion for Ellie and for everyone involved in Longniddry Primary School.

title: services-to-be-held-in-musselburgh-to-remember-well-known-nun
story: Sister Bernadette died peacefully in her nineties on March  at the Sisters of St Paulrsquos Convent and Care Home in Birmingham.She served St Annersquos Convent and Care Home in Windsor Gardens, Musselburgh, for  years, during which time she endeared herself to residents, relatives and staff.She was a familiar sight walking along the streets of Musselburgh and Portobello, as many of the nuns have done over the last  years since they arrived at St Annersquos to establish a rest home.Born in Burton-on-Trent, she joined the Sisters of Charity of St Paul the Apostle and taught in its schools in South Africa for more than  years.On herto England, she worked in parishes in Shropshire, Lancashire and London before moving to St Annersquos.She spent every spare minute knitting teddy bears, hats, scarves and gloves for children in Romanian schools and for St Annersquos summer fayre to raise funds for the residentsrsquo outings.Two years ago, due to failing health, Sister Bernadette retired to the convent and care home in Birmingham.A spokesperson for St Annersquos said: ldquoThe sisters wish to thank all the wonderful people in Musselburgh and Portobello who helped Sister Bernadette in her works of charity. She endeared herself to all she met by her gentle smile and kind greetings.ldquoAlso a huge thanks to all the bus drivers who made sure she ed home safely, especially in the wet and windy weather, and for whom she had a great respect and appreciation.The first Mass of Remembrance will be held at the chapel at St Annersquos this Sunday at .am. Entrance by Ashgrove. The second takes place at Our Lady of Loretto Church on Newbigging, Musselburgh, at .am on Wednesday. Everyone is invited to attend.

title: fourteen-musselburgh-area-projects-win-share-of-funding
story: This follows a public vote online and at a series of drop-in roadshows as part of the initiative organised by Musselburgh Area Partnership.The results of the poll were announced at an event in The Brunton on Saturday afternoon.The area partnership received pound, as part of the Scottish Governmentrsquos Community Choices Funding for   to give people a direct voice in how funds should be invested on priorities in their local areas as part of participatory budgeting .This was supplemented by funding from the area partnership, which allocates a budget from East Lothian Council to a iety of local priorities and initiatives.A total of  projects were shortlisted ndash  applications were received and an independent  considered them to ensure they met the guidelines and aims.The successful projects which will receive funding are:Iain Clark, area partnership chairman, said: ldquoYour Voice Your Choice  has been our second participatory budgeting initiative in our community. This has now seen  fantastic projects receive funding to help tackle poverty and reduce inequalities.ldquoI am extremely grateful to the community for voting and their support in deciding what projects they felt would make a dference. I am also extremely grateful to the many volunteers who worked tirelessly to make it all happen.ldquoMusselburgh Area Partnership will be excited to see the successful projects come to fruition and these projects will be monitored and evaluated over the next  months.Stuart Baxter, area partnership manager, said: ldquoI would also like to say a huge thank you to the community empowerment team at the Scottish Government, the Democratic Society Scotland and PB Scotland who offered help and advice throughout.ldquoA special thanks to all the groups who put forward bids and took part in the event and to all the community who took time to vote and help Musselburgh Area Partnership achieve its priority of helping to tackle poverty and inequalities.ldquoI would also like to acknowledge the financial support from East Lothian Council that underpins the work of the area partnership. This helped them secure the pound, external funding from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Community Choices Fund.

title: pavements-to-be-dug-up-over-next-nine-months-as-ultrafast-broadband-comes-to-musselburgh
story: The company says that this will help bring ldquoultrafast broadband speeds of up to Mbps ndash the fastest widely available speeds in the UK ndash to the area.Speaking at a meeting of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council last week, Eddie McGuigan, the companyrsquos community liaison officer, said that the project to lay fibre cable underground would get under way in mid-April.He said: ldquoWe will be in Musselburgh itself for the next eight or nine months, certainly until Christmas time.He added: ldquoThe idea is to give everyone the opportunity to get the cable.ldquoItrsquos a great thing for businesses and homes that use a lot of internet and wi-fi.ldquoThe downside to that is we are going to have to do some work on your pavements. We do about  metres a day, so wherever we are, we come and go quite quickly.He added that trenches would be created and high-pressure air used to blow a high fibre cable through.Mr McGuigan said that small cabinets, which are connection points for the network to residentsrsquo homes, would also be ldquodotted around areas.He stressed: ldquoWe donrsquot put them in corners or outside peoplersquos front windows. They canrsquot be in the line of sight of someone and we keep them away from driveways.ldquoAll the work we do is on adopted council land, so we speak to the council beforehand and get the notices in.ldquoIf we need to go into any private estates, shared drives and private roads, we seek way leave which is permission to go in there. If we donrsquot get that, we donrsquot go in.Small diggers will be used to carry out the work and soft areas will be dug up by hand.Mr McGuigan added: ldquoThe barriers will go upthere is a driveway and we will make sure itrsquos covered. We have ramps to go over, so everyone can get in and out.ldquoWe will dig up the pavement ndash unfortunately there will be a scar. We do it the same colour as the pavement. If itrsquos slabs, we will lt them up and put them back down. If itrsquos mono block, we have special mono blocking teams. If itrsquos just concrete, we use the same colour concrete. We will have multiple crews in multiple areas.He said that letters with his details would be sent out to local residents, adding: ldquoIf there is anyone on night sht, we will work round about that.Mr McGuigan said the work would start at the Fisherrow Harbour end of Musselburgh, with Wallyford the next phase, then Tranent and Port Seton.Information events will be held and a pop-up gazebo with information will also be located in the town centre.A company spokesman added: ldquoWith a Mbps connection, files, films and games become unbelievably quick to stream, download and upload.

title: first-dunbar-parkrun-to-be-held-this-weekend
story: The Lochend Woods Parkrun starts on Saturday morning, with runners covering a five-kilometre course in Hallhill.A trial took place on Saturday morning and Lynne Lewis, event director, was pleased to say things had gone smoothly ahead of the real thing starting at .am on Saturday.She said: ldquoThe parkrun trial happened in the most horrendous conditions.ldquoWe had  runners who braved the conditions and a lot were families, with mums and dads running with their children.ldquoWe tested all the kit on Saturday, tested the timer, uploading the times and that was all done on a test system.ldquoWe are expecting, hopefully, not too big a crowd ndash we could get  people running.Parkrun was formed in England more than  years ago by a group of friends who met each weekend for a jog.Until earlier this year, there were no parkrun events in East Lothian but Dunbar is set to join Meadowmill, near Tranent, in flying the flag for the county.Participants can either walk or jog the route, with a team of volunteers working hard for more than six months to see the event created.Mrs Lewis, who has taken part in more than  parkruns, said: ldquoIt is really about getting the message out there that parkrun is for everyone.The course starts at the running track outside Hallhill Sports Centre and is a figure-of-eight shape, comprising two laps of . kilometres.The course heads west away from the centre on tarmac paths around the sports pitches, then s towards the centre and heads into Lochend Woods, before ing towards the centre and repeating itself.Funding for the initiative has come from a number of local organisations, including the townrsquos running club, community council and Rotary club, as well as Viridor, EDF ndash Torness, Team East Lothian and Improve My Running.For more information, go to parkrun.org.uk lochendwoods

title: haddingtons-swimming-pool-to-close-for-nine-weeks-for-refurbishment
story: The pool and health suite at the townrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre is due to shut in April to allow operators enjoyleisure to update the pool hall, which dates back to the s.Essential maintenance and interior deacutecor works will be carried out at the sports centre, off Mill Wynd.Bill Axon, enjoyleisure general manager, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be working with our partners, East Lothian Council, to bring to fruition the upgrade of the pool hall at Aubigny Sports Centre for the benefit of our customers.ldquoIn a coastal county such as ours, being able to swim is a key le skill, as well as delivering numerous health and wellbeing benefits.ldquoAs East Lothianrsquos charitable sports provider, enjoyleisure is delighted to offer swimming opportunities across the county.ldquoIn order to deliver on our aim to inspire active communities, we realise our facilities have to be as inviting as possible. This refurbishment will truly revitalise the swimming pool within Haddington for the benefit of all.One of East Lothianrsquos original sports facilities, lsquoHaddington Swimming Poolrsquo, as it was first known, opened in September .The much-loved site consists of a four-lane swimming pool and East Lothianrsquos only dedicated infant pool.Currently, the facility welcomes about , bathers to the pool each week for swimming lessons, AquaFit classes, swimming club training, school and public use.enjoyleisure, which operates leisure centres in the county on behalf of the council, is working on plans to give the pool hall a facelt from its existing s facade.Currently, the work is scheduled to take place over a nine-week period from April .The refurbishment plans include the complete replacement of custom-fit ceiling window  and a new roof covering.Inside the pool hall, following a complete drain of both pools, a light and bright ceiling covering will replace the outdated wood cladding.A new energy-efficient lighting scheme will be fitted which it is hoped will transform the look and feel of the facility.Existing wall tiles will be replaced with wall liner  to complete the new look.While the pool and health suite will close for the work to take place, the rest of the centre, including the gym, dance studio, sports hall and cafe, will remain open.For more information on the refurbishment plans, go to enjoyleisure

title: tims-tales-leave-only-footprints
story: PRESSMENNAN Wood lies hidden at the foot of the northern slope of the fantastically named hill Deuchrie Dod, just a mile away from the beautul old village of Stenton. The wood surrounds a lake of the same name, which is actually a reservoir created  years ago.Pressmennan Lake is nearly km long and meanders through the wood, giving the appearance of a river rather than a loch. In summer, the lush canopy of trees which surround the lake can engulf the senses, and for a moment you can be fooled into thinking you are in the middle of an ancient forest.And in a sense, you are. The wood is a fragmentary remnant of the ancient oak wood which once covered most of our county. Records show it existed in medieval times, and Irsquom sure well before that.Much of it was felled, so tradition tells us, when the warship The Great Michael was built on the order of James IV around . This ship was famously constructed using the oak woods of Fe, but such was the size of the vessel that wood from where was also needed, including Pressmennan.Yet the wood seems to have survived, and in  the felling of trees here is said to have been stopped due to its importance as a habitat for the kingrsquos deer.It remains a place rich in wildle. Roe deer still roam free amidst the trees here. They are creatures of woodland magic, and native to these isles. They are small and nimble-footed, and will dart into the undergrowth at the sight or sound of approaching danger. They have short antlers and a tailless rear, which usually has a white patch. This is the part of the animal you most likely see, as it quickly bounds away from you.The wood is full of other wildle: owls and bats, hares and foxes, stoats and weasels, and, according to the Woodland Trust Scotland, who own and care for the wood, otters have also been seen in the lake. The birdle here is likewise rich, and there is a crescendo of song in the spring. The trust acquired the wood in  and is slowly restoring it to its natural character, planting oak and other native trees.We arrived at the wood last weekend, on a day of changeable weather, but laden with the promise of spring. There is a childrenrsquos map provided by the Woodland Trust and it proved a great hit for my kids, who followed the loch-side path looking for the features identied.These are wood carvings and sculptures made by artist Robin Wood. Part of the trail includes doors and windows in the trees which are said to be the homes of magical creatures called the Tootflits and Glingbobs.My children, well-versed in the folklore traditions of our county, know all about faeries, brownies, selkies, kelpies, witches and wizards. But Tootflits and Glingbobs were new to them, and to be honest myself as well.They are mythical creatures created by the artist and trust to provide a sense of wonder and adventure for children as they explore the wood. You can search for their homes and the wood sculptures along the way.And so we set off on our adventure of discovery. The path by the riverbank needs care with wee ones when wet, but it whispers magic. Ancient oak trees line the banks of the lake, their branches dipping into the water.These old trees were still leafless, biding their time for the arrival of spring proper. But they were a spine-tingling sight, a reminder of what once was here in abundance. But then, as we ventured deeper into the wood, we made a less pleasant discovery.Some people had decided it was a good idea to hammer coins into the sculptures, and even into the living trees. We found the homes of the Tootflits, and at their door was a pile of rusting coins which had clearly been left as a gt or good luck charm. Rusting coins also lay all around the base of the tree.I understand the desire to leave a gt or charm for a magical creature, but polluting and damaging nature with the ultimate symbol of materialism was, for me, horribly ironic.We removed what we could, and my daughter Skye searched for a more suitable gt. She found a small lsquofaerie cuprsquo, which was the cupule of an acorn, and placed it on the doorstep.ldquoThere, she said, with a sense of satisfaction.We continued our search but we found every sculpture defaced in the same way. One had actually collapsed due to the splintering and rot caused by the coins being hammered into it.The final sculpture was a frog on a log. It too was peppered with coins hammered into its body. In the universal measure of things, this damage was insignicant and perhaps even well-meaning, for I assume it was done by people who came to enjoy the wood and merely wanted to leave their charm here.But eventhere was no malice, it was a desecration. Then my heart tore as I watched my children scrape their fingers as they tried to pull the coins from the poor creature. But they were mostly rusted and too well-embedded.As we left the wood, I was reminded of a famous quote, attributed to the Native American chief Seattle: ldquoTake only memories and leave only footprints.The word lsquophotosrsquo is often used instead of memories but the message is the same, and now more powerful than ever. Itrsquos a worldwide issue ndash the desecration of natural sites by people who unthinkingly want to leave their mark. The coins that werenrsquot rusted we put in a charity box.The experience affected my daughter.ldquoCan you write about what we found, dad, and ask people not to do that  said Skye at bedtime. ldquoAsk them to find presents in nature, like faerie cups or stones or fallen branches or pine cones or berries, or even make a love heart shape in the ground. Faeries donrsquot like metal anyway or need money.And I promised her I would. As she slept, I kept my promise.

title: prince-of-wales-honours-cubas-national-hero
story: Charles stood in silent contemplation as a large wreath of roses was laid at the open-air monument to the famous essayist and poet in Havanarsquos Revolution Square.Fidel Castro, Cubarsquos former Communist ruler, would address the people close to where the prince stood before the ceremony began, giving speeches at important moments.Surrounded by imposing ministry buildings, the heir to the throne, whose we Camilla was nearby, walked behind two soldiers who held aloft the large floral tribute made of roses and then laid it at the stone monument.The heir to the throne touched it briefly before taking a few steps back and pausing to look at the wreath.The British Embassy in Havana has described the royal visit to Cuba as ldquoa historic moment.It tweeted: ldquoEverything is ready for today when TRHs The Prince of Wales and The Duchess of Cornwall arrive in #Cuba for the first official #RoyalVisitCuba.ldquoA historic moment for both countries.Charlesrsquos visit offers an opportunity for the UK and Cuban governments to forge closer ties in the wake of the soft diplomacy employed by members of the monarchy, who use it to make friends and build bridges during foreign tours.A spokesman for the couple, who arrived in the ministerial jet RAF Voyager, said: ldquoTheir Royal Highnesses are looking forward to experiencing the culture and meeting the people of Cuba.There was another milestone as it is believed to be the first time an RAF plane has landed in Communist Cuba, which had very close ties with Russia during the Cold War.Later Charles and Camilla were given a tour of the museum dedicated to Marti inside the monument which stands over  metres tall and dominates Havanarsquos skyline.The Prince of Wales and The Duchess of Cornwall tour the Joseacute Martiacute exhibition, learning more about his le. #RoyalVisitCuba pic MqtTtAMdmdash Clarence HouseMarch , Curator Eva Maria Diaz told him about the writerrsquos le and the history of Havana, which prompted Charles to point out that Britain had once occupied the city during the th century ndash ldquobriefly.As they left he told her: ldquoIrsquove learnt a great deal about Jose Marti.Saying that he would like to spend more time in Cuba, he joked: ldquoYou might get fed up with us very quickly.The Joseacute Martiacute Memorial in Havana pays tribute to the essayist, poet and national hero of Cuba.Their Royal Highnesses attend a wreath laying ceremony at the memorial. #RoyalVisitCuba pic CsTrXpbmdash Clarence HouseMarch , He added: ldquoI am sorry to have dragged you in on a Sunday. I hope it is not inconvenient for you.Ms Diaz said afterwards about the prince: ldquoHe knew that Havana was under British power in the th century. It was a very brief period.ldquoHe said that he would like to have more time to continue the visit. He was especially interested in Jose Martirsquos le and work.ldquoI told him that Martirsquos writings were published in  books, including literary, political and journalistic works.

title: brexit-the-week-ahead
story: ndash Monday March Mrs May will convene her Cabinet on Monday morning before updating the Commons on the Brexit process following last weekrsquos European Council summit, where she agreed to delay Britainrsquos departure past March .Parliament will then debate an amendable Government motion on the Brexit deal, which gives MPs a chance to put their favoured outcomes to a vote.A proposal backed by Sir Oliver Letwin, Dominic Grieve and Hilary Benn, seeks to pave the way for a series of ldquoindicative votes in the Commons on Wednesday, effectively taking control of the Brexit process out of the hands of the Government.Mrs May could table secondary legislation which must go through the Commons and Lords by Friday to remove the date of March  from Brexit legislation.Mrs Mayrsquos effective deputy David Lidington has promised to introduce a process for MPs to debate potential Brexit outcomes over the following two weeks.ndash Tuesday March Tuesday has been suggested as a possible date for the third ldquomeaningful vote ndash known in Westminster as MV ndash on Mrs Mayrsquos Withdrawal Agreement.Downing Street says that no date has yet been fixed for the vote, which must come by the end of the week.ndash Wednesday March MPs led by Sir Oliver will hope to seize control of parliamentary time to force votes on Brexit options on Wednesday.Mrs May will also face Prime Ministerrsquos Questions.Friday March Friday is no longer Brexit day, with EU leaders having offered to delay the departure until April MPs do not back Mrs Mayrsquos deal, or until May they do.Leave-backing walkers who have taken part in the Brexit Betrayal march from Sunderland are due to arrive in London on Friday.

title: sports-direct-says-its-debenhams-proposals-are-better-than-insolvency
story: The billionaire said in a stock market update that an offer to buy Debenhamsrsquo Danish business, Magasin du Nord, for pound million, revealed last week, is one of several offers that Sports Direct has made to put the department store chain on a more secure footing.Sports Direct added on Monday that its proposals are better than the ldquomultiple insolvency processes Debenhams is considering as it looks to restructure.ldquoThe offer for Magasin is one of several offers that Sports Direct has made to provide the board of Debenhams with a valid alternative to its apparent view that that multiple insolvency processes are required to address Debenhamsrsquo current liquidity concerns and to facilitate a wider balance sheet restructuring, the sportswear firm claimed.As part of the plan, Mr Ashley, who owns just under % of Debenhams, would become chief executive of the ailing high street firm.For its part, Debenhams has put in motion plans to secure pound million in new funding from its lenders and pursue a restructuring plan which would wipe out existing shareholders, including the Sports Direct founder.Sports Direct said this is ldquonot a workable solution.But Debenhams has dismissed Mr Ashleyrsquos alternative proposals, arguing that they do not address the companyrsquos funding and restructuring requirements, and adding that the tycoonrsquos appointment as chief executive would be a conflict of interest given his ownership of House of Fraser.Responding to those claims, Sports Direct said it does not consider House of Fraser to be a competitor of Debenhams.ldquoIn any event, were Mr Ashley to become CEO of Debenhams, he would, as previously announced, step down from his roles at Sports Direct. He would also be subject to fiduciary duties to Debenhams, it said.ldquoSports Direct would strongly recommend that the Debenhams board reconsiders the offers made by Sports Direct to date and their own duties as directors of Debenhams.Mr Ashley also lashed out at a ldquolack of engagement and the ldquolimited access to information provided to him by Debenhams.

title: smacking-ban-legislation-announced-in-wales
story: The Welsh Government wants toremove the common law defence of reasonable punishment which is currently available to parental figuresaccused of assault or battery against a child.If passed the ChildrenBill would act as the first ergence of core criminal law between Wales and England, where parents would still be able tolegally physically punish a child as long as it is deemed ldquoreasonable.The Government-led bill is being supported by a number of organisations including the NSPCC, Barnardorsquos andAction for Children, and comes as a private members bill in Scotland is currently being considered by MSPs which would remove the defence ofldquojustiable assault in Scots law.Walesrsquo deputy minister for health and social services, Julie Morgan, said: ldquoWe are sending a clear message that the physical punishment of children is not acceptable in Wales.ldquoWhat may have been deemed as appropriate in the past is no longer acceptable. Our children must feel safe and be treated with dignity.ldquoAs one of the most progressive nations in the world when it comes to promoting childrenrsquos rights, I am proud this Welsh Government is legislating to bring an end to the physical punishment of children in Wales, further protecting childrenrsquos rights.The bill will now be scrutinised by AMs, with Welsh Government sources confident it will be passed by the National Assembly and brought into law after achieving Royal Assent by Spring .The Government says the legislation will be accompanied by an awareness-raising campaign and support for parents.Research published last year found % of parents of young children in Wales disagreed that ldquoit is sometimes necessary to smack a naughty child, while the Parental Attitudes Towards Managing Young Childrenrsquos Behaviour  survey found only % of parents with young children reported they had smacked their children in the last six months.The legal defence of ldquoreasonable chastisement has been used in law since  and is currently available in England and Wales for parents or adults acting in loco parentis against charges of common assault.The most recent figures available show between  and  there were  cases where the use of the defence resulted in an acquittal of a defendant or a discontinuation of proceedings against them in England and Wales.Wales would join the  countries around the world which have already banned the physical punishment of children, including Greece, Latvia, Albania, DR Congo, Kenya, with Sweden being the first to do so back in .Viv Laing, head of policy at NSPCC Cymru, said: ldquoItrsquos wrong that children in Wales have less protection from assault and that a legal defence which does not exist when an adult is hit can be used to justy striking a child.ldquoWe have long campaigned for equal protection for children and we strongly believe a change in the law is a common-sense move. Closing this loophole brings Wales in line with dozens of countries across the world and is simply about fairness and equality for our children.Professor Russell Viner, president of the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, said: ldquoWhen a parent raises a hand to a defenceless child, whether thatrsquos a smack, slap or another physically harmful behaviour, they have lost control.ldquoResearch tells us that children who are physically punished are more likely to have poorer mental health and physical well-being and when they grow up, are more likely to engage in self-destructive or antisocial behaviour. Hurting a child isnrsquot acceptable and it is a form of child abuse.But the plans have been criticised by the campaign group Be Reasonablendash backed by The Christian Institute and The Family Education Trust ndash which said the legislation would criminalise parents.Spokeswoman Lowri Turner said: ldquoIt is disappointing that the Welsh Government has decided to press on with this unnecessary piece of legislation that will do nothing to protect children, but will criminalise loving parents.ldquoAs we have seen from a slew of Freedom of Information requests, parents suspected of smacking face suspension, investigation by the police and social services, and prosecution.

title: call-to-crack-down-on-unqualified-scots-identifying-as-electricians
story: Tory Jamie Halcro Johnston described the lack of regulation in the profession as an ldquoanomaly and has urged the Scottish Government to take action to ensure the title of electrician is protected in law.Over  professions are currently protected in law, including registered gas engineers, but not electricians.Mr Halcro Johnston said that he will introduce a membersrsquo bill to the Scottish Parliament aiming to address the issue.In a debate on the subject in October, MSPs from across the parties at Holyrood gave their support for providing protection of title.Mr Halcro Johnston said: ldquoFor too long, the Scottish Government has dithered around the regulation of electricians.ldquoIt has been discussed and discussed again, without any real commitments ever seeing the light of day.ldquoWhen I speak to people about this campaign, the first reaction is usually surprise that anyone can call themselves an electrician without any qualication.ldquoWhen so many other trades and professions are regulated, it seems the position of electricians is more of an anomaly than anything .ldquoMost people donrsquot consult electricians on a regular basis and arenrsquot always confident about the qualications of people they employ. This should provide some additional protection to consumers.ldquoElectrical safety is vitally important. Every year, there are fatalities caused by electric shocks and fires caused by electrical mals. It is important that people carrying out electrical work are qualied and able to do so.ldquoI was pleased to get so much support from across the political parties when this was debated back in October and I would hope that support would carry across to introducing a Bill on the subject.Skills Minister Jamie Hepburn said: ldquoThe serious concerns raised about electricians are being considered fully and we are committed to continuing to work in partnership with all stakeholders.ldquoDuring a debate in Parliament in October last year, I offered to meet with any MSPs to discuss these issues further. Whilst others have made contact, Mr Halcro Johnston has not taken up this offer.ldquoFollowing calls for further regulation, we formed the Electricians Working Group to bring the industry together and attempt to build consensus for a way forward.ldquoAn independent analysis of research, leading to a risk assessment and business case on the way forward, is due to be presented to the Scottish Government later in March.

title: we-are-f-says-official-report-on-impact-of-brexit-on-rural-scotland
story: A document published by Scottish Rural Actionfeatured a side banner on page four with the statement.It was one of a number of banners attributed to participants in a workshop which asked them to imagine what newspaper headlines they might expect to see after Brexit.Amanda Burgauer, SRA chairwoman, said that the exercise had been used as an ldquoicebreaker and that several of the participants had used ldquoearthy language in describing their feelings towards Brexit.The comments are only explained on the following page, saying they had been put forward by those taking part in the workshop event.Ms Burgauer said that she would flag up the ldquodesign and layout issue with the SRA design team.The Scottish Government has said that although the SRA report was funded through its Brexit Stakeholder Fund, it had no editorial role.The report will be launched at an SRA event with cabinet secretaries Mike Russell and Richard Lochhead in Elgin on Monday.Its findings also detailed the potential impact of Brexit on rural Scotland, suggesting that it could lead to ldquost century clearances, with a loss of freedom of movement resulting in signicant depopulation.Further concerns raised in the report, taken from conversations with rural communities, also included the risk of EU funding being lost post-Brexit and potential damage to social cohesion.Speaking about the report overall, Ms Burgauer said: ldquoThis report is about giving voice to a rural point of view that is rooted in Scotlandrsquos people and places, rather than its rural industries.She added: ldquoThere is widespread anger and frustration across rural Scotland, but that anger isnrsquot solely about Brexit.ldquoIt was clear from workshop discussions that Brexit is compounding long standing concerns about rural equity and fragility.ldquoBrexit was described as the lsquostraw that breaks rural Scotlandrsquos backrsquo, with people pointing to structural fragilities across rural communities.ldquoParticipants generally believed that an historic over-reliance on EU funding to lsquoprop uprsquo rural areas makes rural Scotland particularly exposed to future loss of EU support.Speaking ahead of the reportrsquos launch, Constitutional Relations Secretary Mike Russell said: ldquoThe Scottish Government is committed to ensuring the voices of rural communities are heard and I commend Scottish Rural Action for the work it has done to achieve this.ldquoThe findings in this report are stark. Taking Scotland out of the EU against our will removes us from a market which is eight times bigger than the UK alone.ldquoRural communities are deeply worried about the impact of Brexit on their lives. From funding and trade to community le and the workforce, many believe the effects will be nothing short of catastrophic.ldquoThis is sadly yet another example of just how damaging Brexit will be for Scotland.A UK Government spokesman said: ldquoThriving rural areas with strong, sustainable economies and vibrant communities will continue to be a priority for the UK Government when we leave the EU.ldquoWe have committed to establishing a UK Shared Prosperity Fund, which will cover Scotland, to increase productivity in areas where the local economies are furthest behind.ldquoWe have also confirmed that we will maintain the same cash total in funds for farm support until the end of the Parliament.

title: scotland-would-be-biggest-loser-from-abolition-of-erasmus-scheme-after-brexit
story: More students north of the Border choose to study and train in the EU through the Erasmus scheme than in nine other areas of the UK.The Erasmus programme, which was set up in , allows students to study or acquire skills in another EU country.The Prime Ministerrsquos Chequers agreement promised to ldquoexplore participation in the scheme, but it was not mentioned in the political declaration on the future relationship with the EU that May negotiated.Around , students from the UK take part every year, of which , study abroad, and Brexit has placed a question mark over whether the scheme will continue.It was revealed last week that students currently on the programme are in the dark over funding and accommodation, and some iniduals fear they could be left without health insurance.Figures released by the Peoplersquos Vote campaign, which backs another referendum, break down the the number of UK Erasmus students by  areas. The statistics, which are based on yearly averages covering  to , show that , students from Scottish universities participated in the scheme during this period.In second place was London, with ,, followed by the South West on , and , for the South East.Universities such as Edinburgh, Exeter, Leeds, Durham, Nottingham, and Bristol would be among the biggest losers.Popular destinations include France, Spain, Germany, and Italy.David Rodger, , who is originally from Stonehaven, studied French and German at St Andrews University, and spent a year in Leipzig.Back at St Andrews, he met his girlfriend Andrea, a Spanish student on an Erasmus year at the Fe university.ldquoIrsquove always loved languages and therersquos no better way to learn one than fully immersing yourself in a new city and culture. Erasmus offers kids from Scotland a brilliant opportunity to live and study at top Universities across the continent, he said.Richard Lochhead, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Further Education Minister, said: ldquoBrexit poses a direct threat to our membership of Erasmus, particularly in the event of a no deal.

title: independence-activist-promises-never-to-vote-snp-again-over-sturgeon-picture
story: Jonathon Shafi, who was a senior figure in the Radical Independence campaign, said it was ldquoabsolutely sickening to see Sturgeon photographed with Alastair Campbell, who worked for the former Labour Prime Minister during the run up to the Iraq war.Sturgeon was one of the high profile political figures at an anti-Brexit rally in London yesterday, at which campaigners called for Article  to be revoked and a second referendum to be held.The huge show of support for the UKrsquos place in the EU attracted cross-party support, with politicians such as London Mayor Sadiq Khan, Lib Dem leader Vince Cable and deputy Labour leader Tom Watson joining Sturgeon.Ahead of the rally starting, former Labour MP Douglas Alexander appeared to have a dig at the SNP by saying he was attending for his friend Blair McDougall, who led the pro-UK Better Together campaign: ldquoAnd everyone like him, near and far, who opposes nationalism  isolationism.Campbell, who was Blairrsquos spin doctor in opposition and then took on a similar role in Downing Street, was also on the march and a photograph of himself with Sturgeon was posted on his Instagram accountCampbell wrote: ldquoSorry Douglas. title: joanna-blythman-reviews-stravaigin-glasgow
story: We find ourselves here in the bar, by accident rather than intention. On an otherwise somnolent Tuesday lunch time its really welcoming: chilled, but not dead. It feels lived in, well curated, timeless: zinc-topped bar, old church chairs, skew-whf glass lampshades, coppiced branches laced with twinkling lights, aged, sturdy tobacco brown wood ling and reclaimed planks brightened by hints of arsenic green paint. Staff behave like people who are happy at work.: Pasha, North Frederick Street, Glasgow. Restaurant review by Ron MackennaNominally a ldquoside dish at a mere pound., this intelligently composed winter salad of bitter chicory, peppery rocket, and walnuts that taste freshly toasted, all tossed in a Stilton vinaigrette, is just what I fancy. We marvel at the ldquosmall plate of mussels. Its pound. tag is deceptive. Itrsquos enough for lunch, an ample bowlful of bivalves, plump, fleshy specimens, in a thick Asian soup thatrsquos not for wimps, a thicker version of Indian rasam, aromatic with lime leaf, cinnamon bark, cloves, star anise, and just a hint of sweetness to round it off. Therersquos also a blisteringly hot flatbread to dunk into it. It tears away in circular strands, a bit like a Malaysian roti cenai. Heaps of effort is packed into this dish, yet itrsquos inexpensive.Hake, a special on todayrsquos menu, is a pleasure to behold, a steak cut from the centre of a well-proportioned specimen impeccably grilled under its cape of green herbs. Wild garlic scent wafts up from the plate. It twines around roasted slices of purple potato, which have that rewarding, elusive flavour and floury texture thatrsquos now such a rarity because these characteristics have been bred out of modern ldquomultipurpose commercial potato ieties. Squash pureacutee adds a brightening dash of orange to the opalescence of the fish, setting off the emerald garlic leaves, and the muted imperial purple of the potatoes.The fishcake is also made with hake, and once again, we taste Stravaiginrsquos very evident proficiency with the use of spice. Its innards have the hue of brown crab meat, I guess from a fresh-made curry paste, which lends sharp backbone, perhaps from tomato, with the earthy undertow of turmeric. The necessary oiliness of its breadcrumb jacket is offset by juicy ribs of crunchy, refreshing pak choi that have had a fleeting visit to a searingly hot wok. A runny-yolked poached egg, and satiny, coriander-speckled Hollandaise layer, add wanton enrichment to the already satisfying fish.We catch up with the plum frangipane tart in a just-out-the-oven state. Its thick, yet barely cooked centre, rather like liquid marzipan with opulent dark plums bleeding into it, is only just bound by a taut corset of gloriously buttery, almost butterscotch pastry. This paragon of patisserie perfection is partnered beautully by a scoop of toasted almond ice cream, which tastes like essence of the very best Spanish nougat. Apple and olive oil cake from the daily menu hits that bliss point between too hot to eat and freshly baked. Moist within from the oil, and subtly conveying all the grassy, green flavours in it, it really does taste ine. The exterior is an up hill and down dale landscape of biscuity crust and apple chunks. Translucent pools of sharp, punchy green apple compote, and amber caramel, accentuate the winning sweet-sourness of the cake, while lemony cregraveme fraiche ice cream decisively nudges this dessert away from excessive cloyingness.In its own words, Stravaigin has been ldquowandering since  and ldquoshowcasing Scottish produce that isnrsquot tethered to its roots. Despite all those fawning write-ups that might encourage smugness, it doesnrsquot put a foot wrong.Stravaigin,  Gibson Street, Glasgow   Food:  Atmosphere:  Value for money:  Service

title: iain-macwhirter-to-stop-mays-thelma-and-louise-dash-for-the-no-deal-cliff-edge-mps-must-now-take-back-control
story: I donrsquot want to go back to anger and denial. Wersquove had enough of that from Theresa May. The can has been kicked down the road so often that you just want to jump on it and flatten the damned thing.This week we go back to the bargaining stage, but we may not even get that. Parliament has been given an extra fortnight for May to preicate, and for the Commons to avoid coming to a consensus.At least the prospect of no deal on Friday might have concentrated minds, like an execution, and forced MPs to seize the reins of power from this battered and friendless Prime Minister.Instead, we have another fortnight to learn what we already know: that MV seems as remote as ever, and Theresa May wonrsquot give up on it.The European Unionrsquos political leaders were, of course, acting in their own best interests on Thursday. Having listened to May ramble on incoherently for  minutes, the  concluded that, yes, she really is daft enough to let a no-deal Brexit happen.Well, they can live with thatthey have to. But what they werenrsquot prepared to do is allow her to blame the European Union for the breakdown so, to coin a phrase, they took back control.The heads of government offered to delay the Brexit deadline until May ,she gets her deal through Parliament, or April she doesnrsquot. They will go the extra mile, explore all options, and then even offer a longer extensionall  fails. Itrsquos jaw-jaw not war-war, and they are the virtuosos of jaw-jaw.Though in truth, Brussels doesnrsquot really know what happens when the talking finally ends.The problem with the European Union is that they expect political leaders to behave as rational agents, who seek the most advantageous outcome. They donrsquot have protocols to deal with mad-as-a-hatter prime ministers and a parliament that has lost the plot.The UK has decided to have a collective mental breakdown, in full technicolour, and will not be talked out of it by boring bureaucrats with their seemingly sensible solutions.After , days, the simple fact is that UK still doesnrsquot know what Brexit means. That image of the cat manically scratching at the door, and then refusing to leave when itrsquos opened, is only too apt.Everyone knows that the obvious destination for a country like Britain, which has vital trading links with Europe but doesnrsquot want to be part of the political union, is to join the European Economic Area, now dubbed ldquoCommon Market ..That alone allows friction-free trade, avoids an Irish border and halts these daft, wartime preparations for no deal. .There has always been a majority in Parliament for soft Brexit, everyone says so. But as I pointed out last week, our system seems incapable of distilling compromise from the mash of party interests.MPs say they want to reach across party boundaries, but as last weekrsquos walkouts and tetchy letters confirmed, they donrsquot really. No-one wants to take any responsibility, no one wants to blink first, no-one wants to make the first step.Yet to halt Theresa Mayrsquos Thelma and Louise-style drive to the clf edge, ministers and MPs will have to remove her from office, probably through a confidence motion, and set up a kind of provisional government.They need to force the long delay she refuses to contemplate. This weekrsquos indicative votes on their own wonrsquot cut it. The nightmare, indeed, is that nothing gets a majority.The Westminster system requires a semi-dictatorial Prime Minister, with an unassailable majority, to . But May is a dictator without an army. She has no majority, yet perversely behaves asshe still has one.What residue of authority she possessed evaporated after her petulant outburst against MPs on Wednesday. Even Labour MPs who were tempted to vote for her deal, like Lisa Nandy, were so outraged that they resolved to vote against her come what may.What can you do with a Prime Minister who wilfully alienates her potential allies Theresa May actually had a point about Parliament only being able to agree on what it doesnrsquot want. We all thought that the problem was the Withdrawal Agreement, the -page legal document signed off by May last year, which contained the infamous Irish backstop. But we now know that this is not the case.Last week, Labour declared that they did not have any problems with the Withdrawal Agreement or the backstop, despite Jeremy Corbyn having condemned it in November. He said then that Mayrsquos Withdrawal Agreement was ldquoa half-baked deal which Britain cannot leave, and the backstop would deny Britain ldquothe sovereign right of any UK parliament to unilaterally withdraw from any backstop.All Labour now wants is a tweak to the Political Declaration ndash that non-binding, non-legal compendium of cliches, aspiration and wishful thinking that accompanied the Withdrawal Agreement. I seem to remember writing that to say this was woolly would be an insult to sheep. So why has it become a deal-breaker The blame obviously lies principally with the Prime Minister ndash a woman so bereft of vision and leadership ability that she shouldnrsquot be left in charge of a milk float, let alone a country.She could have offered Labour anything they wanted: full consultation, customs union, workers rights, environmental standards, regulatory alignment. It would have meant little because the Political Declaration is non-binding. Instead, she has made a fetish of inflexibility which is the worst failing in a political leader. She is in love with her idea of herself as a ldquobloody dficult woman, and thinks that backing down, resiling, is a betrayal of her sex.That is why I ended up voting for the petition to Revoke Article . To my horror, I found myself agreeing with Nigel Farage and Michael Portillo that the only real choice,Parliament cannot act, is between no deal and no Brexit.The only certain way to end this horror show is to pull the plug, halt the madness and pretend the last three years never happened. EvenParliament does end up backing Mayrsquos deal, which of course is still possible, it wonrsquot put an end to this nightmare.The Withdrawal Agreement is only the start. It deals with citizenship, the orce bill and the Irish backstop. Negotiations over Britainrsquos future trading relations with the EU have yet to begin, and will take two to four years. Four more years of this would be beyond endurance.And it wonrsquot be Theresa May who is doing the negotiating, but perhaps Boris Johnson, or some other Tory leader. If voters were fully aware of this fact, Irsquom sure that the parliamentary petition calling for Article  to be revoked would top  million within the week.

title: how-orkney-reinvented-the-future-with-hydrogen
story: ldquoIn , it said, ldquoOrkney was the first to generate hydrogen from tidal power, using electricity to split water into hydrogen and oxygen. Actor, environmentalist and hydrogen-advocate Leonardo DiCaprio shared that video on Instagram. It has been viewed , times. The world had its eyes on little Orkney as a possible beacon of low-carbon hope.It is not the first time Orkney has been there first or best. Back in , the first grid-connected wind turbine was erected in buffeting gales at Costa Head. In , a giant experimental concrete turbine, the largest of its kind, was inaugurated on Burgar Hill. Orkney was where, in , the European Marine Energy Centreinstalled Scotlandrsquos first grid-connected tidal device, and last year, a flagship tidal energy turbine generated more electricity in its first year than the whole of Scotlandrsquos wave and tidal sector produced before it.The carbon intensity of the electricity that Orkney generates and feeds into the main grid is almost the lowest anywhere in the world, at just g CO kWh. Only El Hierro, in the Canary Islands, beats it.Hydrogen is Orkneyrsquos latest possible game-changer. New projects on the islands are fitting ferries to run on the gas, which is produced from local renewables.Hydrogen boiler heating systems are being fitted into a primary school. Orkney Islands Council, a signicant force in the developments, is running a fleet of hydrogen-fuelled vans.A key player in these changes is the wave and tidal test and research centre, EMEC. Its hydrogen manager Jon Clipsham says that a favourite phrase at the centre is ldquothe art of the possible.ldquoWith these projects wersquove proved itrsquos possible, he says. ldquoIt also has to happen. If it doesnrsquot wersquove got nothing to hand over to the next generations, because Irsquom more than of the opinion that the climate is changing, and quite rapidly now.What is it about these islands  Partly, of course, itrsquos the climate and location itself ndash the rapid tidal currents that run through its sounds, the constant winds. Itrsquos also that for decades it struggled with the fact that it is an island, connected to the mainland electricity by an undersea cable, and suffers the worst fuel poverty in the UK ndash partially caused by being off the gas grid and stuck with one of the highest rates for grid electricity.Hydrogen technology has developed in Orkney, in part, because the islands had a problem.This archipelago with its now more than  wind turbines and developing tidal renewables was generating too much electricity for its own needs ndash it now produces the equivalent of % of its electricity demand ndash and wasnrsquot able to send more down the line to the grid.The cable connecting to the mainland could only carry a small fraction of what it was generating.Communities had erected wind turbines but were not seeing the expected revenue s, and were having their generation curtailed, some to just % of what they could generate. So great is the problem that currently there is a moratorium on further wind development.Clipsham says: ldquoThe huge expansion in renewable energy led to a point where there was more energy being produced than we could feed back through the cable to the mainland. That meant those who had invested in wind technologies were unable to get the revenue they were looking for.This was particularly frustrating, says Clipsham, because the sheer abundance of natural wind and tide resource on the islands meant ldquoyou could deploy  times, possibly more, of it than what wersquove currently deployed.Community groups had bought in to the idea of using the feed-in tarfs as a means of generating revenue for projects and services but werenrsquot seeing the expected payback. A further issue is that while Orkney is host to incredible renewables potential, the communities also suffer the worst fuel poverty in the UK. A factor in this is that there is no gas grid on Orkney and the electrical supply can cost as much as p per kWh, making it among the highest in the UK.The Orkney community was looking to find answers to these problems and, around seven years ago, EMEC began to look at using the renewables technology to make hydrogen by electrolysis. ldquoEMEC has always been very future-focused, says Jon Clipsham, ldquoand hydrogen is not new. Itrsquos been around for a long, long time. Iceland had a boom-and-bust cycle. But we began to look at it.ldquoThoughts of how we need to decarbonise the world were very present. By  , things had really some momentum and we decided to go for hydrogen.The first project was Surf rsquonrsquo Turf, a wind and tidal energy project that was all about grid balancing, in which energy was harvested when it couldnrsquot be put into the grid, stored, and regenerated as electricity when there was the opportunity to export it.However, it was quickly recognised that the hydrogen could also be used as a fuel. ldquoThe premise, says Clipsham, ldquoshted from grid balancing to setting us off on the journey which we are now well advanced with, towards having a fledged hydrogen economy.As part of EMECrsquos European Union and Scottish Government-funded Big Hit project, hydrogen heating boilers are being fitted in a school on the Orkney island of Shapinsay. Meanwhile, a car ferry is under construction which will run on hydrogen, and this year will see the installation of a hydrogen system into one of the ferries currently running between Shapinsay and Kirkwall.Such technological development seems timely. In December last year, Maersk, the worldrsquos largest container shipping company, announced it aimed to be carbon neutral by  ndash currently it is looking at biofuels.Clipsham is interested in how these hydrogen and renewables technologies might scale up or be adapted in dferent locations. ldquoCan the learnings we got here be transitioned  Yes. Energy systems are becoming increasingly decentralised, so yoursquore breaking things down into smaller chunks, so you might see some of the knowledge wersquove gained on Orkney rolled out and used on a block of flats, or a housing estate or a leisure centre.There is a sense on the island right now that what they are doing is being watched. Steven Bews, a builder who grew up on Shapinsay where the Big Hit project is based, is, as chair of Shapinsay Development Trust, involved in his community turbinersquos integration in the project. ldquoWe do feel a wee bit like the whole world is looking at us, he says. ldquoI keep seeing it on social media. Orkney and the Big Hit project is being highlighted and itrsquos good to see that the wider world is aware of us.For Bews, the idea that he is getting to be part of a greener future is as important as the local benefits. ldquoTherersquos a feeling that you are being environmentally friendly in what yoursquore doing. Yoursquore trying to lever the whole industry away from carbon and on to renewable green energy ndash and while it is in its infancy, I believe hydrogen has the potential to eventually replace a diesel and hydrocarbon-thirsty transport infrastructure.The awareness of climate change is strong on the islands. Almost everyone has some story to tell of its impact. Adele Lidderdale, hydrogen project officer at Orkney Islands Council, observes: ldquoYou see crop failure. We had flooding over the past  years that we didnrsquot previously see. We know the impact that the environment can have on day-to-day le.Lidderdale, whose great grandfather came from Orkney, grew up on the islands. Her husband grew up on Shapinsay, where one of the key hydrogen projects is based. ldquoWhen yoursquore in such a small community you see the impact first hand. You have to answer to the community. I think thatrsquos part of the unique mixture of why wersquore able to get these things done. You know that yoursquore going to have to answer to the people who are going to be affected by any decisions you make.Part of the appeal of the Orkney hydrogen project is that it shows on a small, very human scale, how hydrogen could become part of the answer in a low-carbon future. Nigel Holmes, chief executive of the Scottish Hydrogen and Fuel Cell Association, sees great promise in what is happening on the islands.ldquoOrkney is almost like a microcosm of some of the things we are trying to tackle. We can show how we make the hydrogen from renewables, we can move it around, we can store it. We can show how it can be used in transport. We can show it can be used for making power, also for heating. The project helps people to appreciate the interconnected nature of some of these networks ndash because itrsquos all there in one place.Clipsham has watched the project develop and believes that one of the key things about the Orkney Islands is the people. ldquoPeople are starting to ask, lsquoWhy is all this going on in the Orkney Islands  Yoursquove got , people, but theyrsquove now got a portfolio of about  million euros of hydrogen related projects happening.rsquo And thatrsquos a very good question.ldquoBut when you go to the Orkney Islands and you talk to some of them, you realise why. Because there is such a positive can-do attitude. If you give them a problem they will work out what they can do to find a solution. Andit isnrsquot obvious theyrsquoll go out and look for it. There is an absolutely amazing attitude up there.

title: si-ferry-talks-football-in-our-latest-cool-conversations
story: A le less ordinary: Partick Thistle director Jacqui Low talks politics, bereavement and smashing the glass ceilingIt helps that Ferry is a former footballer and that some of the people he interviews are just his mates, people he might chat with anyway. Just a year ago he was in the twilight days of a football career, playing for Peterhead once a week, coaching Under-s for Celtic, doing the Royal Mail night sht and sitting about the house all day. Then he got a call from some producers, who had a ldquowee idea. They found his Twitter stream funny and wonderedhe would be up for interviewing fellow footballers. Thus Open Goal was born.His shows, he says, work because they are so informal. ldquoWe donrsquot wear suits. Wersquore not good looking. Wersquove not got our hair tied back. We donrsquot use all fancy words. We always wanted to keep it like that because the thing is as soon as you start taking yourself too seriously you just end up like every other football show on the telly.The success of the show isnrsquot something he takes for granted. ldquoI think Irsquove said beforeI get paid to do anything involving football I feel quite privileged because thousands of people over the country would love to do anything involved with football and get paid for it. I had a normal job. I delivered kitchens for a bit. And I was the worst. I was terrible at it. I used to bash the kitchens up. I had no clue what to do it.Part of Open Goalrsquos secret is that the interviews reveal the struggles and some of the messiness of being a player. ldquoPeople hold these players up on a pedestal, says Ferry. ldquoThey think theyrsquove got the best lives in the world. Theyrsquove not got a care. But on interviews, yoursquoll hear they went through bad times. People like to hear that, that these guys donrsquot just live in perfect eight-room houses and drink champagne every night.Recently Open Goal triggered a bit of social media backlash when they interviewed Robbie Savage. ldquoWe had a bit of stick because hersquos down in England. Butyoursquore just going to keep it to Scottish football yoursquore going to run out. it was quite bad for a couple of nights but then when the episode went out I got a dferent they changed their opinion on him, which is why we do the show.But the April  Cool Conversation wonrsquot just be about players ndash it will be about the world of football and what happens when it meets the media and social media. Jacqui Low, one of only three women directors in the Scottish premiership and chair of Indigo PR company, will bring her years of communications experience to the discussion. Amy Irons, daughter of former footballer, Davie Irons, grew up in the world of football and now presents sport for the new BBC Scotland news show, The Nine.Book tickets at www.lateralcity events

title: revealed-1370-a-month-to-live-in-squalor-in-scotlands-temporary-accommodation
story: Or a sad single room in a grotty hotel, with no cooker and no fridge, where youre not allowed to talk to anyone for fear of drug-dealing or youre locked outyoure back five minutes late at night All over the country, people are being put up in smelly, rundown private hotels and BBs due to a lack of social housing stock. And in Glasgow the taxpayer has to pay pound a week ndash thats pound a calendar month ndash for the privilege.Solicitors, charities and politicians have today called for the government to open its eyes to the scandal affecting the countryrsquos homeless population and have accused those in power of squandering taxpayers cash while keeping the most vulnerable in poverty.The director of Scotlandrsquos largest housing charity, Shelter, said the situation was due to ldquodecades of underinvestment in social housing.Residents are provided with a room, a bed, a kettle and a wardrobe. In some cases they have their own bathrooms, while in others they have to share a communal one in the corridor. In one BB, residents were forbidden from talking to each other or going to each otherrsquos rooms, while in another the doors were locked at midnight and anyone not back by then would be out for the night.Cooking facilities were rare, and in most cases residents lived on non-perishables such as instant noodles, biscuits and junk food.For the money costs to be accommodate in these places ndash pound a month ndash an "impressive drawing room conversion" is advertised for rent in the heart of Glasgows west end.The flat in an "elegant sandstone townhouse" comes with a modern kitchen, mezzanine, "stylish" two-piece bathroom and separate toilet, and is "exceptionally well-placed for local amenities and excellent transport links".And for less than that, pound a month, a two-bedroom semi-detached mews is available for rent, including council tax bills.The "elegant" property is also in the west end of Glasgow, and boasts two large bedrooms, a kitchen, bathroom and access to a garden.In Bearsden, a three-bedroom refurbished villa is on the market for just pound a month.This, they say, is only adding to or creating more problems in terms of mental health issues, addiction, isolation and unemployment.Lorna Walker, a partner at Govan Law Centre, said: ldquoThis isnt the best use of taxpayers money, when they could be putting it in to accommodation that is of a decent standard and putting it in to helping people get their lives back on track the way they want it."It is not a good way for taxpayersrsquo money to be spent at all and the authorities need to open their eyes and see that.ldquoThe law in Scotland on this issue is some of the best ndash it is very clearly written, and it is clear how it should be applied. Unfortunately, it isnrsquot working in that way.Ms Walker added that many of her clients are keen to get back to work, but as they are unable to afford to pay the extortionate pound-per-month rent and try to save for a deposit for their own homes, they are stuck in a ldquovicious cycle.She said: ldquoUnless you are on a great wage, itrsquos a lot of money to pay. Itrsquos more than most peoplersquos mortgages.ldquoPeople may be stuck there for months and sometimes years, and itrsquos a vicious cycle ndash they lose skills, they become isolated, they dont make relationships.ldquoWe have clients who have been in these places for years, or people who may have been in one then moved to another and another, theres no support to get them into a flat.He explained: ldquoWhile the cost can be high, it is what we must pay to ensure people have somewhere to live when they are homeless.ldquoThese are the consequences of decades of underinvestment in social housing.Annie Wells, Scottish Conservative MSP for Glasgow said: ldquoThese revelations expose an extremely poor standard of living for those housed in these places. Itrsquos simply not good enough, either for the vulnerable people living there or the taxpayer.ldquoHow can we expect homeless people to get their lives back on track when theyrsquore being left in such unacceptable conditions Labour housing spokeswoman Pauline McNeill said: "This is simply scandalous but it wont be fixed until we end Scotlands housing crisis."The government need to be much better at preventative work and stopping people getting to this point in the first place."That means properly resourcing public services, looking at how we can make the private rented sector more affordable and preventing evictions, as well as building more homes for social rent."Current legislation on breaching suitable accommodation must be properly enforced and responded to ndash that simply is not happening now."Glasgow City Council said: ldquoThis is a national issue, and it should be noted that the charges for this type of accommodation go to support the whole homelessness system and the charges levied reflect the overall costs of the service."The charges are iniably met from Housing Benefit, which is paid for by the UK Government.ldquoWe are implementing the Housing First programme which will see people given permanent accommodation with appropriate support at the first time of asking.

title: david-pratt-in-the-eye-of-the-storm
story: It might as well have devastated the dark side of the moon for all the attention it has been given. But then itrsquos in Africa, isnrsquot it  These things happen there, have done before and doubtless will again, so whatrsquos new If I had the proverbial pound for every time such cynical responses have crossed my path after ing home from covering humanitarian crises across the African subcontinent and where these past decades, then the needy coffers of aid agencies would be better off right now.It was late on Thursday, March  when Cyclone Idai made landfall off the coast of Mozambique, before hurtling itrsquos gargantuan wrecking ball of mph winds, rain and floods into Zimbabwe and Malawi, causing devastation across swathes of all three countries.What Idai left in its wake has been described as perhaps the worst weather-related disaster ever to hit the southern hemisphere. Already the United Nations World Food Programmehas declared the flood crisis a level three emergency, putting it in the same bracket with Yemen, Syria and South Sudan.In terms of its impact for the estimated . million people caught up in this maelstrom, it meant storm surges of up to  feet deep, creating on the Mozambican coast what BBC reporter Fergal Keane flying over the area by helicopter called an ldquoinland sea.For tens of thousands it has meant being trapped by floods, landslides, flattened homes and flooded communities, with crops, roads and electricity supplies wiped away. More than , people needed emergency evacuation in the Mozambican port city of Beira alone where the cyclone made landfall. Some initial reports estimate that % of Beira, Mozambiquersquos fourth-largest city, with more than , residents, may be damaged or destroyed. Without electricity Beira has found itself in the dark and has become a ghost town at night.Many in Beira and where were stuck on rooftops or on tiny islands of land surrounded by water with no food, clean drinking water or shelter. There have been cases of women with babies trapped in trees and other lucky survivors pulled from neck-deep water.As ever in such situations, many of those worst affected were already the poorest of the poor, susceptible to hunger and disease even before Idai dealt them such another cruel blow.ldquoThis will have the worst impact on those most vulnerable, says Caroline Rose, Medecins Sans Frontieres head of mission in Mozambique.ldquoItrsquos those who have small, fragile houses that are worst impacted, as they are always the people without the means to build a new house.
